ya know, I bought this game for $4 and was really enjoying it. I mostly bought it for myCareer, and got about 3-4 hours into my playthrough and was getting decently immersed. and then, all of a sudden, I get drafted by a team and get into the NBA, and the game won't let me simulate when my player isn't on the court. if I want to be able to simulate the game to the point that I can ACTUALLY PLAY IT, I have to tab out of the game 5-6 times and then it will suddenly give me the option. when you start the game, you are just a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ scrub that sits on the bench because you have like 60 overall rating. so essentially, I spent $4 on a brick because anytime I want to play the myCareer mode, I get to play for about 1-2 minutes before I'm subbed out and have to start trying to force the game to actually work like it should. I've tried all of the fixes I've seen online. none of them work, in fact they just tank the game down to about 10 fps.the devs over at 2K games are actually genius, because I have to spend about 4 hours going through pointless dramatics just to be drafted and actually start getting subbed out. so this issue is not even apparent until after you cannot refund the game. â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ this game, â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ the devs for allowing this to still go unpatched for over a year, and â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ the Lakers. this is what will cause people to start pirating your â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ games.

This game is one of the worst games i have played this year, if not ever. MyPlayer can't hit wide open slightly late/early shots with a 70 overall, but another player with a 60 overall can hit 70% contested shots. I really want to know where is the logic in this game because so far after many attempts i have failed to find it. Every team plays with the ball very selfishly not willing to pass to me while im open in paint. Every time i ask a player to pass the ball to me, i get ignored with no obvious reason behind it. As an examle, Trae Young can hold the ball for 8 seconds with nothing happening and he causes no violation, but if i hold it for 8 seconds, i get 6 different violations and my score goes from C to F+. Hitting a green shot is rarer than your parents buying you a Bugatti for your 16th birthday. Defense of the AI is non-existent. If i go for a layup i get guarded by the whole team like im a national threat with a bomb in my hand meanwhile a SF from the opposite team can score a 3 while being wide open because why not. The AI teammates block you while you are trying to get to the player you are guarding while he is moving at 300 miles per hour and then its your fault and you get a defensive breakdown. Upgrading your player does as much good as drinking acid. The movement is garbage, the animations are trash, and i could very well see why Ronny 2K would sell the game for 4 euros. I am honestly surprised at why would new players buy it. Even 4 euros is expensive for a game thats about as good as a game developed by a rookie programmer. I mean hey there must be a few positives right? Sike you thought. If this game is "good" then im also 8 foot 9 irl. I dont know why i thought that it would be a good idea to purchase this game. I am still in disbelief because of my poor decisions. I could have bought 2 large chocolates and it would have been a better investment. At least i wouldve enjoyed the chocolate. â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ this game and everything it stands for. Suck the right side of my left nut 2K.

Actually the worst FM of all the series I've played.I have been playing FM since 2008. And I can honestly say that this one is the worst one I've played. I know the users have been saying this is a glorified roster patch for 50 bucks. I would say this version is not worth it even with the sale. Match engine is made horribly making me question (yet again) the development capability as much as their knowledge of football altogether. They clearly wanted to implement the line breaking with throughs, but they didn't have the capability to code the defender's to react so they made the 1 on 1 chances : scoring ratio ridiculously high to offset that. I think this may be the last FM series I would purchase because it's never been this clear that Sports Interactive actually doesn't care at all about the user feedback.

Best version of FM for quite a few years. Didn't bother with FM19 but FM20 is a definite big improvement from FM18. The new development area is a huge plus and I like the Club Vision page which breaks down how well you are performing in your role. Feedback from staff is much better integrated in these new versions and the tactics area is vastly improved.Match Engine still could do with improvement however and the Press Conferences have barely changed in a decade with the same cookie-cutter responses. That area really needs an overhaul. Overall it's a definite recommend especially if you've been away from the series for a couple of years.

Overall I am a fan of the FM games, as I still seem to pay for them year on year. There are many comments here regarding the price for the game, I think the price is OK, given the depth of the game in terms of content and replayability. A few minor points to pick out for those that have played it over the years. Pro's:- You do feel more in control of your team than in previous years. Through the interactions, youth development, tactics and new staff roles added. Loan Manager = much needed when I get a bit excited with my first big budget. - Great lower league experience. I think the game is best played bottom up. Starting with a low level team (I started with Dulwich Hamlet). It can get very same-y if you start with a decent team. Cons:- Promises promises. Some of the mechanisms and potential responses to player promises are lacking. For example, I signed a player and promised to strengthen my team. I did (well I thought I did), I was unbeaten for the season and champions league (up to this point) and the player still complained and wanted to leave. Therefore the player rationale was based on reputation of players, rather than performance of players signed. This happened a few times therefore I stopped promising players anything before I signed them (which meant losing a few). - I am not sure if it was just my game, however after being 7-8 seasons in, there was an abundance of world class 17-20 year old strikers coming through. When checking the top scorers of the leagues, they were all created in game and all had ridiculous stats. I would compare it to 8 or 9 Messis coming through at once? WILL SOMEBODY THINK OF THE CHILDREN - Press conferences. Eventually the questions become very, very repetitive and you will always have the same answer for the same question. If you leave it to the Assistant Manager, they tend to go rogue every now and then, therefore perhaps some way to automate, but in line with some preferences would be good.

However, somehow the reported major flaws (overpowered long-range strikes, under-powered 1-1 goal scoring) are gone. I actually wonder why since I am not aware of a patch that should have fixed these flaws.All-in-all, I really love playing this version now. The game is worth the price, but you will need an outlet for the inevitable frustration it will cause you. Defenders can't keep themselves between attackers and their goal, attackers can't convert one on one chances, goals fly in from corners and indirect free kicks, players demand new contracts with 3-4 years remaining on their current one, your team will win 5 matches in a row then lose 4 straight, and so on. Frustration is guaranteed because the match engine is wonky and the form effect is too strong. And still, I have to recommend the game because it is addictive and makes you want to keep playing despite its obvious flaws.

Game ran really well on my laptop that is less than a year old, which is use for work every day and also complete all my open university on as well. So when my trial was up i thought why not, so i spent Â£39.99 on the game. 232hrs later the game has decided not to work or when it does its slow and takes 25 mins to complete 1 game. Ive been online and checked everything i need to ref my system etc making sure everything was up to date. Gave FM20 priority you name i have tried it. Contacted Steam, no good what so ever. Went direct to Sega who told me to try everything i have been doing. To be honest im disappointment in the product and service. Don't buy. Absolute waste of time. Match engine is still broken as it was all these years. Nothing changed. My last buy was 2016. Decided to purchase this one bcz of positive feedback. Only to see that players at England Championship level doing things that in real life you'll not see from player at League two level. Defenders will kick the ball to coner whenever they meet the ball near the back line. Strikers and wingers will try to score from impossible angles instead of passing the ball across. AI will score in added time every fourth/fifth game while you will score a goal in last minutes once a season. Defenders  stay cool while opposite striker paves his way for the shot. Keeper throwing the ball directly to the opposite striker leg - how often you see this in real life? Maybe once a season, here, in FM it happens frequent (remember we're talking about Championship level players)... and a lot of other ridiculous things that I just have no time to describe here...Don't get me wrong, there are a lot of cool stuff around the match, but when it comes to the match itself the gameplay is ruined...This is my last buy of this seriesNew update: Forget about broken match engine. The entire game is broken. At one day, after you've worked hard to bring your team to where you are, the game will start crashing with "FM 2020 encoutered  a serious problem and will close" message. You'll not be able to load this save anymore. Then after going back to a very old save,  one day, out of the blue, the game will start crashing with "FM 2020 stopped working (staging) and will close". No recover from this... DO NOT BUY.

Football Manager is one of those sporting based franchises which receive a yearly rendition, with what looks like from the outside, nothing more than just a roster refresh. To an extent, that is true with Football Manager, with the database updated for the 2019/2020 football season, a seemingly insignificant change to justify Â£30 more of your money. However, what Sports Interactive are consistently capable of, is bringing a range of quality of life improvements as well as the occasional larger update that don't necessarily reinvent the wheel, but refine it to it's truest form.Football Manager 2020 is the best version of Football Manager, hand down, in the same way that Football Manager 2021 will most likely surpass the present iteration of the game. If you are a new player to the franchise, the in game tutorials and menus allow any user to customise and change the many different roles and responsibilities to their liking. Meaning you can slowly ease yourself into the fantastic depth that Football Manger provides for club management. Whilst if you are a returning player, the improvements to aspects like the match engine and the development centre should allow a greater sense of success in the short term while allowing the ability to feel like you have left a legacy with a club in the long term.Many people may be put off with Football Managers limited licenses in comparison to games like FIFA, with the lack of Premier League licenses, with the exception of Watford, potentially disinteresting a core English audience. Although that being said, the use of the EFL and National League licenses within the game should encourage more lower league management, which in my opinion, provides a much more enjoyable experience than starting your saves at already financially secure and successful teams. Moreover, the complications surrounding the German national team and the Brazilian Leagues can also detract from your experience. However, the ability to install a wide range of graphical and database improvements provided by the fantastic Football Manager community can resolve such issues, these improvements may not be directly supported by Sports Interactive due to legality issues, again surrounding licenses, yet they are perfectly easy to install on the PC version of Football Manager (Simply Google how to install Facepacks, Club Badges, Name Fixes, Entire new divisions, etc).Football Manager cannot be learnt to play in a day, as much as that may differ certain players, its simply the reality of this game. Football Manager provides a incredible depth to club managements and players will be learning certain mechanics and nuances to the games up to years after playing it. I, myself still learn small things about the game after playing games in the franchise for 4 years now. Yet, If you are willing to brave the seemingly steep learning curve at first glance and learn the core mechanics to this game, I strongly believe you will find yourself hooked into crafting your own narrative and stories through this digital football world.

As someone who has bought pretty much every year's instalment of Football Manager for the last 10 years running, I have to say this one is a massive disappointment.The match engine is absolutely abysmal, and simply provides absolutely no reward for creating a good tactic and carving the opposition open as your players will miss one-on-ones and clear cut chances over and over again, irrespective of how good they are supposed to be as a finisher. You will repeatedly find that the game punishes you for playing football, and instead rewards tactics that only focus on Pulis-style hammering of crosses and long balls into the box and set pieces. It is just so horribly demoralising to see your team achieve great stats, dominate possession, shots and clear cut chances, only to watch highlight after highlight of your top strikers repeatedly missing ridiculously simple chances.I would strongly advice you to avoid this game at all costs and simply play an older version of Football Manager where the engine actually works to reward effective tactics and doesn't leave you pulling your hair out when your key striker, a player who on my save was ridiculously overpowered in terms of his attributes for his level, misses 95% of one-on-ones, spurning 6 clear cut chances only for the opposition to score two headers from corners and win.Horribly unrewarding, do not play.

The match engine leaves so much to be desired. Wide players will attempt to score from the byline several times each game instead of passing to an unmarked striker. There are almost no forward passes centrally and no through balls at all, so most goals are the result of a winger, inside forward or overlapping back crossing to the other side of the box where an onrushing winger will score. Or a set piece which seems overpowered to compensate for the relative lack of goals from open play.Occasionally a midfielder will score a screamer from 30 yards from a cut back but strikers score mostly rebounds and headers from set pieces and get very little service in normal play.It's very possible to win most your matches by having world-class inside forwards but I finally got fed up with every attack looking the same.

As a person who used to mainly play FIFA for the career mode unaware of Football Managers existence until 2017. I am astounded at how incredible this game is and I am disappointed in myself I didn't switch to this years ago. The detail put in to this game is incredible. If you're a true football fan to put it quite lightly, you will adore this game. At first I had a look at the menu I was handed and I'll be honest, I was confused. Never been more confused in my life. Gradually as I went on I learned more and more things and even now I'm still learning. I've only played so many hours (due to my low attention span I really can't just play the same game for hours and hours on end).I can understand why when the matches actually take place the graphics aren't too great but it seems we've become lost where graphics are actually better than the rest of the game. I'd take Football Manager having the fantastic opportunities and detail given to me opposed to nice graphics for a 10 minute interval where I don't even have control directly over my players. It simply doesn't bother me and it shouldn't bother you. A million percent there could be improvement in graphics but it really shouldn't matter.Personally, I bought this on sale for around Â£20 and if I'm being honest I feel like that was the right price for me to pay for this game. I'd advise to buy it on sale especially now considering FM21 is coming out soon which I will be honest I probably won't buy until it goes on sale. That's just me though, trying to save some money and feeling when the time is right.If you're a massive football fan who loves and is intrigued with the game additionally love the tactical and managerial side, this game is for you. Don't think it's easy and you'll understand everything straight away otherwise you will not have a fun time!

Usually a huge FM fan and consumer but this years game isn't my favourite, if you've got an older version - stick to that.Problems with this game: Overall - Mainly the matches themselves seem to be utterly unpredictable, completely unmanageable and none of the information stats seems to match up to  to pre-game instructions and player stats.More specifically.- Too many 1 vs 1s (missed and created) - Too many volleys, header, long shots scored by all players or players with low stats- Too many goals scored by simply tackling defenders - regardless of press instructions- The team doesn't really feel like you're managing it. At all levels and situations - making a change in seems to yield rather random results, FM19 seemed to have a better balance of cause and  effect.- Zebre FC (although i understand why)-  I think too many chances per game, although i haven't studied the statistics compared to reality-  seems impossible to 'tighten up' or try and maintain possession. -  I'm not overly bothered about match day graphics, as i like 2D Traditional (top down) view. - Alot of aimless punts up the pitch/bad computer AI. - Teams seem incapable of moving up the pitch as a unit. - Lots of stuff appears to happen in the last 10 mins- Not totally sure all the pre-set style of tactics are necessary.Anyway - usually a huge fan of this game and left frustrated with this version of it. I see others are having similar issues and  i think these have been acknowledged.

Football Manager has been an important part of my life since 2016, the game has come very far and that is reflecting in this year's edition. The in-game mechanics and engine have been improved immensely. The AI now develops better tactics and squad building which punish the player that doesn't critic his tactics and mange his own squad and makes each match even more intense, keeping you on the edge of your seat until the final whistle. Great work by the team over SI and I look forward to playing this franchise for many years to come.

Having played all editions since like 2005, I can say that I finally reached a point where I had enough with this game. It's decent as all the games from the series are, it's undeniable that for all of us football fans there's always a smile to be attained every year when we take our team to the glory and that alone keeps making us play it with a smile everyday. But I think it's time for me to just say, I had enough with buying it for full price and it being exactly the same thing, over, and over, and over again, and guess what, the problems that it always had are still there and I don't think SE will ever fix them.The game's randomness is it's main problem, it's inconsistent as hell as it's always been and it can become frustrating to a point where you just don't feel like wasting time on it anymore. A good example of this randomness is with injuries, god awful, it doesn't happen in a football team for in less than a month 10 players or more of your team getting injured even when you made sure you have the best physios and conditions in the club. It also doesn't happen your striker with amazing attributes failing 10-20 goals per match, it also seldomly happens that your same striker fails to pass the ball to a colleague that is alone 10 cms on the side and can easily score. Also, players are human beings, and as any conscious human being, you cannot expect a poor team to reinforce your squad with millions when they are not available, but in this game, every single player will create drama for every little thing, and it becomes TERRIBLY annoying at some point. We know now that we live in an era where football players cost a lot of money, but man, after 5-6 seasons, even the lowest of players cost over 5-10 millions and it just becomes impossible for you to deal in any sorts with other teams. Also I doubt that any big team would be able to spend over 600 million every year like I see in this game happening... Another propper example of failure in this game is what happened to me this season, I won a game 4-0 on my first go and I was playing with a team that was inferior to it's adversaries, but not by much, and my PC crashed after. Reloaded the game, and for my surprise I couldn't win that game afterwards anymore for some reason, even though I changed absolutely nothing, now, I normally don't replay games (if I lose I lose, just like in real life, there's always a chance of that happening since everyone has a bad day) but I replayed this game about 10 times and I never won it again. So if that isn't randomness, than what is it? Football doesn't work like that my dudes, of course there's always a chance for any team as long as it's 22 men on the pitch fighting it out, but it puzzles me on how stupid it can be sometimes. I think this algorythm that the game uses, is in no way perfect, but damn, it should've been perfected in 20 years no? It's the least you could do for people that keep cashing in every year.These same mistakes, of course, arguably, are what set this in being a game and not real life, but when you play a game like this for being a simulation, it should be as accurate to the real thing as it can get, and it puzzles me that in 20 years these dudes have not improved one single bit. Now you can come and argue with the "UI has changed, better scouting etc." sure thing, but is it really any way superior year after year? Not really, it is just a different shade of paint on the same painting every year. Cannot in any way recommend this game to anyone, even though I have fun with it as I do every year, and as probably I will keep playing it every year, guilty pleasure I guess or the love of football, or maybe both. But it's getting harder and harder to recommend this to anyone, when it's not a football simulator anymore, it's a randomness simulator with football elements.

Unfortunately, for all the excellent aspects of this game - and there are many - the most fundamental part, the match engine, is so disappointing. It is both limited and repetitive; the lack of variation in highlights, goals and overall play is a let down. If you want to rely on set piece goals to win, you're in luck. There are some great aspects - player development, training, transfers, club philosophy, tactical set up - these have been very well implemented. BUT, following all the clicks, drags and efforts to make things the way you want, the match engine takes one giant safety pin to the balloon that is FM's enjoyment.The ME has never been perfect, or even 'great' in my view, but it has at least in most versions represented your football in such a way you see balance in reward alongside punishment. Not in FM2020 - despite many patches, it is woeful. SI has fluffed it this year. Better hopes for FM2021...

As the years go by, I'm finding it harder to enjoy Football Manager. I honestly don't know how this game is any different from FM19. If Sports Interactive were interested in making a good game, they'd release FM once every 2 years and actually take time to improve things. I've been playing since FM12 and even then people were complaining about the match engine. Disappointing that every edition still has a glaring bug when it comes to gameplay (players not squaring the ball, one-on-ones). And each new FM seems more focused on feature-creep crap like player interactions and adding unnecessary jobs like data analyst and sports scientist. Why are my players always talking to me when the conversation options feel like they're written by someone who has never spoken to people? Why add data analysts when your scouts keep recommending you Mbappe, Aguero and Varane even though you're managing Norwich? FM is getting more bloated with each year and these features have been gradually eroding away at the actual fun of the series. I want to develop unknown youngsters into star players and I want to devise tactics that allow my team to play beautiful football. I don't want to get into an argument with my 18-year-old striker about why I played him as an Advanced Forward instead of a Poacher like I promised. I can understand the realism behind a prima-donna millionaire footballer throwing a  fit but if practically every player in my Vanarama National league team is a ticking time bomb then this game is just nonsensical.$50 for a transfer update and new ways to piss your players off is daylight robbery.

I'm in mid March of my first season and I still have to play matches every week. This game is so unrealistic.In all seriousness though, the match engine is a disaster-class. Bang average at best players employ their 10-11 dribbling skill to run past 3 world class defenders on the regular.You get 1-2 goals disallowed and 3-4 shots hitting the post literally every game. Mediocre goalkeepers manage to parry 15-20 shots per game while their equally mediocre forward teammates convert 2 out of 3.15+ marking defenders make it a point to leave opposing players completely alone, instead marking their own teammates.Defenders pull off sliding tackles on their own teammates in their own box, but absolutely refuse to attempt tackles on opponents advancing towards their goal.And speaking of sliding tackles, on the off-chance someone actually performs one on an opponent, the ball only moves about 5 cm so the tackled player shrugs, picks it up again and continues his run. That's not how physics work, SI!This game actually makes me miss FIFA manager...

I've played FM since the very first Championship Manager series and have been highly addicted. There have been some high water mark moments and some low points along the way - I've also find it hard to justify spending full game price on a game that for all intents and purposes introduces minor tweaks at best.I have long lamented the addition of social media and press conferences into the game and managing a world of pre-madonnas isn't exactly my idea of fun but the game has improved greatly in what you can strip out and give to other people to do in-game. Even if they sometimes drop the ball and you have to bail them out!That said, the game play and quality therein has returned with this iteration - I can honestly say FM20 is going to keep me entertained for a long while yet!

FOOTBALL MANAGER HAS FINALLY GONE MAINSTREAM IT SEEMSFootball Manager 2020 is selling like hotcakes, there have been plenty of records broken with the game this year as Miles Jacobsen has been celebrating on Twitter at every opportunity. It's great for the money men, it's great for Sega, but something has changed with Sports Interactive (SI) with this game. The match engine is an abomination this time around and SI have done little to fix it and Neil Brock has basically dismissed the torrent of negative feedback on the official forum saying that SI are happy with with the match engine. He basically said they don't care about the fans that have helped shaped the game series over the past 25-30 years. This is worrying, it is so broken and unbalanced this time around for a senior figure at SI to think this and communicate this with their most diehard fans clearly shows that the drive of improving fundemental features is gone and that the objective it to fluff the game out with nice sounding but useless features to boost the annual marketing push.I'm so disappointed in this iteration of the series and in my opinion it is the worst Football Manager in many years. The game is jut not fun to play, even with success. There is no way as a Football Manager player of 25 years that I can recommend this game. Football Manager 2021 will be the first game in over 20 years that I do not buy at launch.New comers to the series you will probably enjoy the game as it will be your first and you will likely be drawn in by the depth and all the things that has made the game great for so many years. But extended play will lay bare the awful match engine which will never be fixed.NOT RECOMMENDEDSource: Neil Brock post on official SI forums: https://community.sigames.com/topic/514560-football-manager-2020-january-february-transfer-updates-feedback-thread/?do=findComment&comment=12305407Example of issues with the match engine - number of missed one on ones, the number 10 role being useless and bypassed, too many goals from long shots, awful crossing, ineffective central play making all games feel the same, world class strikers scoring paltry amounts of goals, set pieces and long shots being the main source of goals and many many more (I suggest looking at the thread linked above to see in depth the fundemental and immersion destroying flaws)

Football Manager 2020 (FM20) is a football management game developed by Sports Interactive and published by SEGA. It was released on 19 November 2019. In this review, I will briefly cover Football Manager game play, run through the features introduced in FM20 and provide a perspective on the state of the game.In FM20, you, the player, manage a football team through 118 playable leagues. Of this 118, 26 leagues in 14 countries are fully licensed and another 24 teams (national and domestic teams) are licensed. Within the 26 leagues: French Ligue 1 and Ligue 2, German leagues one to three, and English leagues two to four are fully licensed. The English Premier League, Spanish La Liga, and Italian leagues are not; though the Serie A has 18 of 20 licensed teams.  Game Mechanics / FM20 Features  Football Manager incorporates a variety of features and mechanics; including, but not limited to, 2D and 3D football matches, squad training, scouting and transfers, tactics, and financial management. The series also includes a vibrant modding community. In FM20, SI various smaller features such as Club Vision - long-term club progression, the introduction of the Development Centre, transfer negotiation improvements, better integration of backroom staff into your operations, and match engine and graphic upgrades.I reflect on these main marketed features as small, but solid quality of life features that has a ton of room for improvement in future iterations. Club Vision enables you to consider the long-term aspect of the game, however I found that negotiating a different vision is not user-friendly to do and the Board of Directors offers you little flexibility to amend their vision. Further, Club Vision allows for player negotiations to be interesting by offering players different playing times, but a mechanic that SI should balance because the penalty for not adhering to the playing time is little.More on FM20's features: The Development Centre is a cool feature that consolidates your developmental squads into a single UI. This is a neat addition because you can treat your reserve squads similarly, and staff provide useful contextual advice to you on the progression of players. The changes to backroom staff are visible, i.e. you can select Technical Directors and Loan Managers, but I have yet to see any observations in their role. Lastly, the match engine and graphic upgrades are nice, but the match engine has a lot of room for improvement. If I summarise FM20 by the above features is relevant, yet underwhelming, but nice inclusions to expand on the core game mechanics.  Perspective on Annual Releases  I have played Football Manager since Football Manager 2017. Across these four iterations, I recall that only two of the four (2017 and 2019) made substantial changes to the game. It appears that SI Games has a formula which Year X incorporates large changes and Year Y focusses on quality of life improvements that expand or address concerns on features from Year X.Â I acknowledge the concerns of the community and question the situation: Is SI Games complacent? I think the football management market has a lack of competition and variety. While SI Games makes enjoyable annual games, I think they could address more community concerns, particularly with the match engine and to fix the various glitches and bugs throughout the game. I do appreciate that SI Games is expanding the licensing of official teams and leagues because it makes playing the game a more enjoyable experience. But in saying that, I vastly enjoy the Football Manager series and it is addictive; though sometimes a frustrating experience.  Conclusion  FM20 is an ultimately enjoyable game. It benefits from having a strong foundation of team management and football simulation, at the consequence of visible stagnation to new features and post-launch support. FM20 specifically, has some nice features, but I applaud more the many quality of life changes implemented by SI Games. If you are new to Football Manager, I recommend FM20 at full price. If you own FM19, I recommend the game on sale.  Rating  7.5/10  Pros  * Core mechanics are immensely fun, including team and financial management, and social feeds* Development Centre is interesting and useful* Modest match engine and graphical improvements, including upgrades to manager appearances* Slightly improved press conferences and tunnel interviews; your manual comments can slightly benefit or hinder player morale.  Cons  * Series has a need for material improvement including: more animations and enhancing the fluidity of matches, more applicable feedback from players and staff, press conferences, and financial management such as customising and managing club facilities and managing tickets/negotiating sponsorship deals* Underwhelming Club Vision and player negotiation features* Inability to identify applicability of new backroom staff and the supposed improvements to staff.If you found this review helpful, please give it a thumbs up. If you would also like to follow my reviews more easily, be sure to join my group http://steamcommunity.com/groups/AntwogReviewshttps://store.steampowered.com/app/1100600/Football_Manager_2020/

These recent iterations of the game we all love have felt somewhat soul-less, cluttered, and somewhat contrived. One of the striking disappointments is the SAME media questions being recycled for the 5th year running, which makes the whole thing feel monotonous. Symbolic, really, of how the franchise has lost its beating heart. The game is no longer fun anymore with so much crammed onto the screen (for stats sake) the eyes are overwhelmed by text and numbers on skins that are cheap and garish. The 3d match engine gets worse with each iteration, and 2020's effort resembles a 6th formers animation project, with players gliding surreally gliding around the pitch loosely coinciding with ball movement. Goal replays are dampened as the ball crashes into the net and the spectators remain seated, and then... oh, they're up and celebrating a little while after. The training screen is so busy now, it just makes you want to ignore this aspect of the game because its simply to onerous to manage or understand how on earth any of it will impact upon your team. The Player Search list is now cumbersome with each player listing now 2-3 rows in width which prolongs the process of browsing for players. Since 2017, the joy has simply been sucked out of these games by a developer who seems intent on ripping out everything that was good about the game and replacing it with ridiculously packed screens of mostly inconsequential data. Sega/SI would be better off building a baseline game based on some of the better versions, and simply keep it updated. They'll still be quids in. The constant unnecessary tweaks to the game are killing it.

I have to say I was really enjoying this years instalment of the franchise until they brought out the "match engine fix" patch which took the game from having to be tactically smart and choosing your transfers carefully to "He shoots, he scores". Goalkeepers have gone back to previous games of being redundant (one of the things I liked about this game was that goalkeepers actually made saves, sometimes even when one on one, now they are beaten every time) defending is poor and the whole premise is just who scores the most goals in the game (I know that's how you win games but winning games 5-4, 6-3, 4-3 isn't a good thing, especially as both teams hit the post so often despite how many goals are scored) I've tried different tactics and different teams to see if there are ways to not concede so many goals but there isn't, so just set out an attacking formation and hope you score more than your opponent, the whole thing is luck based now,  if your players are on form that day, you win, if not, you lose heavily and your teams morale is ruined. Such a shame as I would have heavily recommended this game before the update ruined the match engine, It's not a management game anymore, it's just a luck based simulator

There's several issues with this game, a major one is deletion of ALL your player instructions for set pieces if you switch between tactics, the right players will no longer be taking the right positions, the game swaps them all and jumbles them up. Apart from this bug however there are gaping wholes throughout all the game engine, there is essentially no such thing as defending. You can easily conceded a hundred goals a month. The game only recognises attack as a strategy and if you attack correctly you automatically defend, examples including Watford wingbacks on defend against you dribbling past 5 players 90 yards up the pitch cutting inside when they are right footed only and scoring a 30 yard screamer with a long shot rating of 4 and finishing of 6. Expect Raheem Sterling to man mark your players like a good and track back despite pep laying down a high pressing tactic rather than marking. Expect totally phantom tactics regardless of scouting reports such as the opposition defending narrow and man marking when slated for a high line press, you can either press or you can man mark, it also doesn't seem to make any difference what the attributes of the players are the computer can simply play the best tactics against you and their players will fill their roles perfeclty and have perfect squad harmony and passing teamwork no matter having never played that formation against you all season. Whatever you do the entire league will set up specifically to counter just your team including buying players that you need such as inside forwards. The whole game rather than being a challenge seems to be arbitarily cheating against the human player with the entire tactics and game engine and scouting essentially being meaningless, including if you change tactics to spring a surprise the day before the computer will just play with a totally different formation to the one scouted!

I really wanted to like the game... I have been playing FM on and off since 2014, almost always managing my favourite club. After 2 very successful years with the confidence of the board being over 90%, I cannot play it anymore. The board is blocking my transfers cause they want me to sign more players from a specific country outside the EU. I already signed one last year who is now one of their top national team performers, I signed 3 promising youths who will be joining next year, they still block all my attempts to really strengthen the squad. I do not know how this is supposed to work... I do not know if the devs have understood how this works in reality but what they have implemented is totally crappy and a game stopper. Fun fact is that the specific team I am playing used to have two players from that country and now has none... Another issue I dealt with was the fact that the board was aiming at building a new stadium but when they agreed to upgrade the youth facilities this particular goal just disappeared and suddenly, even expanding the stadium was not deemed financially viable... Both these problems seriously affect my game and enjoyment and are by no means realistic.Apart from that, I do not really understand how they can do that, but every year the game feels slower than last year. The match engine is not bad, but still far from being visually up to date, days drag by.. slowly... scouting feels much clunkier, training could use some automations and so on.In all, I do sadly not consider FM2020 as a successful upgrade, I enjoyed FM2018 much more.

So, I have played Football Manager for about twenty years, since the days it was still Championship Manager, back in 2000.The game always had this random component to some aspects but it was fun once you got the hold of it and had your team playing in a consistent way. That is until this year.It seems like the game is set to screw you most of the time. Really.While this is not really something new to the avid Football Manager player, as most of us have experienced a sense of unfairness, at some point, in the game; on this version, you get it most if not all of the time.Mind you that I am an experienced player and I have won, over the years that I have played the game, everything that there is to win and on different clubs.On this year's version, despite winning the league on the first season and having a world class team, after three seasons, I couldn't even be a contender for the Champion's League qualification places. I had some of the best players in the game, like Tonali, Havertz, Ansu Fati, Sancho, Bernardo Silva. I had a dream team, really and I would struggle to beat weak teams. Constantly.I tried multiple tactics, nothing really worked in a long therm. The tactic that won me the league, on the first year, suddenly stopped working even tho my team was actually stronger. I mean, you don't change something that is working and is consistent. Such is the philosophy that allowed me and, likely, most of the players in the game to achieve success, eventually. Even if there were some struggles at the beginning.I tried to have more than one tactic and get my team familiar with those, so I could change if something was not working, I tried multiple approaches with training and team mentality, player instructions and, as stated, even with some of the best signings in the game, it wouldn't matter. AI would score goals, constantly, after being outplayed for the entire match. And yes, I know this happens in real life but it doesn't happens as often as in this game. It's stupid and unrealistic.Maybe, for people who are really dedicated to the game, spend hours planning and reading every detail on the tactics and have a vast knowledge, these issues can be worked on but it's not really a game for the player who just wants to chill, keep things relatively simply and have some fun with their favourite team because, even the experienced player, might get screwed. The game can, indeed, be very gratifying when you win something, specially in the last games of the season, when everything is really close but, believe me, most of the time, it is incredibly frustrating. The possible reward by winning something, even with a top team, is not worth the annoyance and the sensation of wasted time and confusion as to why the AI still manages to beat you against all odds, more often than not.I don't know what SI is doing but it seems like their attempt to make the game realistic has set them on a path where things are out of control, most of the time and you are always on the edge of your seat, on every game, regardless if you're playing against the strongest contender of the competition or a club that is just playing to avoid relegation. You never know if you're going to win, no matter how strong your team is.It is pretty much what some people have been saying here, lately. You will also find many posts on Reddit about this.No matter what you do, it won't make a difference and it is, probably, a bug from some recent update.I liked the previous versions, on past years but I definitely do NOT recommend this game. Save your money, your time and, especially, your sanity.

Despite some good aspects, I can't recommend this game.The match engine is really, really bad. World class strikers almost always miss 1-on-1s. Defenders are horrible at positioning, and let strikers get 1-on-1s all the time - but it doesn't matter, because the strikers surely miss. There is zero reason to play in a counterattacking style in this game. Everyone in the goal area (defenders and attackers alike) look like Bambi on ice, and goalkeepers and defenders look tremendously stupid when they try to clear the ball, but accidentally shoot it into their own net. I like most aspects of this game *outside* of the matches, especially the people management aspects. But the good parts are completely overshadowed by the bad parts. Stay away from Football Manager 2020, and consider getting Football Manager 2008 instead.

Have never written any reviews before, but this game is atrocious. Far worse than the previous iteration, FM 2019. They tinkered with the match engine and it is now an unreliable joke of a simulator with, among other things, an unrealistically high number of one-on-one opportunities.  In poor fashion, they reacted to this by making strikers terrible at finishing the said one-on-ones off. This is absolute bull. (estimate average of about maybe 5-8 a game, often with NONE of them finished off)I got the game a while back, and refunded it after a day or so. I got it a second time against my better judgment and am here writing this after finishing 1 and a 1/2 seasons proper of the game to properly conclude that this game is absolute garbage. I say that knowing how hard some of the developers might have worked and how difficult a project such as this is. However, if it is significantly worse than the previous iteration, then I am fine with being overly harsh in this manner.

good game

I used to buy this game every year from back in the 90's when it was called Championship Manager, with the last FM I bought back in 2014 as the match engine was simply broken. I swore I was done buying the game but relented after 6 years and bought FM 2020. What a mistake. The match engine for fm2020 is even worse than in 2014, how is that even possible? Only one of the many tactical styles of play will ever get you results. You can spend hours setting team and individual tactics just to watch the game show your team following none of them. Constant direct long balls when playing possession build up is a joke, full backs scoring blinders every game while strikers can never convert the way too many 1v1 chances magically created. Defenders that do not play a covering role even when set to with a low defensive line are constantly going high just to then get beaten by a long ball to the striker in behind. It is clear the match engine is not an actual real-life game in motion, but pre-defined scripted plays that you have no control over, nor do your tactics.This game is sold as being as close to real life as a football management game can be, funny how in real life I don't see every team playing route 1 long balls or the gegenpress across the world. Six years in between purchases was clearly not long enough...

Unlike previous years, the engine is â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥. Tactics matter very little and there's very little diversity to what you can play with any element of success. The opposition get in behind every five minutes and no tactical changes nullify it, yet your players will miss one on ones every single time. Strikers getting 6.4s or lower every game is abject, seemingly for no reason, as they get chances, but can't put away routine finishes, despite having 18-19 finishing. And if you miraculously hold out against the one on one over the top ball nonsense, the opposition will score a screamer against you. This season, 10 games in and I've seen such renowned long shot specialists as Kyle Walker, Joe Gomes, Abdoulaye Doucoure and Stefano Sensi score thunderbastards into the top corner. Yet Harry Kane can't score from 5 yards with just the keeper to beat. But at the end of the day, buy the game and play it how you want. But when Danny Welbeck and Adam Lallana score a hat-trick against you, you'll be very, very sorry.

I have been playing this game since the days I had no pubic hair. It was called a bit different back then, posing the -title- winning Championship Manager crown. An era where you just read text about your imaginary joga bonito and had some sheer fun cheering at flashing psychedelic text.Those days are long gone. From Championship, we have switched to just... Football. Do not get me wrong, I'm not another one of those nostalgicphiles, quite the opposite. However, it just incomprehensible that the game is going from bad to worse. DLC level additions year after year, and an ever declining match engine that has just led to today's broken game. We never asked our addiction to follow RTX tech level advancements. All we asked -and to this day, still do- is that what you try to 'design' on a tactics board, is followed to a logical extent on the pitch. Instead of aiming to fix the ice skating phenomena of the motion -wtf is- captured, focus on getting the basics right. The game should all be AI, seamlessly working algorithms, multi million calculations per second that would resurrect ENIAC out of its grave. I fail to comprehend how the match engine is declining instead of improving over the past few months/years. With all due respect to those hard working individuals (I'm sure there's plenty of those) but is the level of staff working in SI declining? From a CX perspective, you consistently present a malfunctioning product, with DLC level additions, at a premium Epsilon Alpha (wink wink) price. Hand in heart, you should take a sabbatical year from production, fix the basics of a functional match engine, and release the next version on September 1st 2021. Yep, the year is not a typo. Riding that early season hype wave may even help you recover the lost year of revenue. I just came across a post from 2010 where a player was complaining about a 3% cross completion ratio. Guess what, a decade later, players with crossing 15+ finish the game with 10-15%. Your team's players crosses will always be stopped by those heroic opposition fullbacks, despite having galloped past them like Usain Bolt against schoolboys. On the opposite end of the pitch, those schoolboys always get their revenge with a staggering 80%+ cross completion ratio! Goal conversion is just like VAR in England. An absolute joke. One-on-ones are still not fixed since...October XX (where XX add the year of your liking). Lukaku level strikers (love or hate), finish two seasons with 8% conversion. Lautaro loves bruising the shins of centre halves by fiercely kicking the s*** out of them (with the ball, no red card material here you naughty minds).Goalkeeper distribution is still as good as CM 00/01. Imaginary. "Ederson with the quick release" remains fiction.Anyway, I could go on and on and on... But truth is, I'm tired. Tired like you start a Champions League final in June with 58% condition... The match engine is just like a hamstring. They think it's healthy and gets torn again. Don't force us to retire, get us a good head of sports science to restore our faith in the parallel universe that we all loved over the years...

First review I've ever left, but feel I need to add a warning here. As of 13 January 2020, the match engine is fundamentally broken - one on ones and headers are almost impossible to score regardless of the level. You'll spend hours trying to figure out a way to convert chances, thinking it's your tactic that's the problem, but the match engine so far this year is just bugged. Look on reddit etc and you'll see hundreds of posts with the same issue.My advice is to not buy this game until they've fixed it - it's a joke that it still hasn't been addressed by now and SI is another company who are happy to release an unfinished, untested product and screw over their loyal customers. They hardly make any changes every year - so why they can't devote more time to QA before release is just negligent. FM has become a cash cow to SEGA in much the same way FIFA is for EA.Notice how you can no longer buy any of the previous years editions of FM which are balanced and just require an updated database to bring up to date. SI and Sega are pulling a fast one.Recommendation: Buy the game in March or April when it's fixed and is 50% of the price.Pros:Dev Center.New analysis tools.New staff roles.Cons: Broken & Unrealistic Match Engine.Very few changes notable from last year.

Many goals gain seem like stupidity and wouldn't happen in a real game. The game scripting ruins it hugely anyone who telling you they enjoyed this and its perfect is lying or a Bot. Everything apart from the matches is superb, best FM ever. The match engine is fundamentally broken - too easy to split a defence open with a long ball resulting in a one-on-one, so SI nerfed the conversion rates of one-on-one chances to keep scorelines acceptable. The result however, is that your world class  striker misses 2-5 easy chances every game. Wingers do not square the ball for strikers, instead preferring to shoot from obscenely acute angles rather than play the ball across the box. Half the crowd is a repeated man in an orange jumper. This may sound minor but it's really immersion breaking once you notice it. You can be a team that plays in blue, and yet over 50% of the crowd are dressed in orange. It diminishes the match experience and detracts from the game as a whole.It's crap like this, broken for 2 months now, I've bought every game in this series since the year 2000, I pre-order every year (literally the only game I will do so with) and said I'll continue to do so until I get burned. Well, SI Games, you've broken me at last. The 'Bugs' section of your forum is littered with these issues that are "under review", well you can consider my purchase of FM 2021 in the same category.Edit: I played a bunch more because apparently I'm a masochist. The match engine is total cack and has regressed massively since FM 2017. Don't waste your money - take up a more enjoyable pastime such as jamming needles in your eyes, you'll thank me for it.

Quite simply put, not worth full price because the match engine is absolutely pathetic. The players stats do not matter and every goal keeper is the best goal keeper in the world. Also no matter how highly rated your strikers are, they will fail to convert 95% of chances. I'd say, either wait for SI to fix this sad excuse of an engine which is surprisingly worse than FM19 or wait for the game to be on a very deep sale, probably 95% off.Update: Tried the latest beta patch, still the engine is broken. The players attributes are still not taken into consideration. Though 1v1 have reduced by around 90%, the strikers of your own team have completely forgotten how to play the game. The wingers have learned how to cross the ball and are more effective now. The defense how ever is still dumb struck over long balls over the head and overall haven't learned how to do their job, which is defending, instead they just turn around in circles and watch the opponents go past them. The cards have certainly reduced, but the foul count is still the same which is a lame way to fix an issue. The tactics and instructions are still a foreign language to the engine because it still calculates the winning chances based purely on the reputation of the club, which again is plain stupid. Advice to SI: Sack your current producer and don't release the next FM unless you fix the most important part of the game.

I really want to give this game a positive review but unfortunately there are just too many problems with the match engine that take away from the "glossy" improvements elsewhere. Sure. There are positives:Board Vision and the fact that clubs are now being picky over who they invite to interviews is both realistic and frustrating (lets be honest, how many Conference National managers get jobs at higher levels unless they get their team promoted - Christ.......even Grimsby just appointed Ian Holloway rather than take a risk on a proven manager such as Dodswell at Havant)Youth Development side of things is good and a real improvement as all fans want to see their clubs develop their youth players.Right........moan time: Firstly......I want to say that I have seen over 1500 football matches live (mainly PL and Championship but also many games in the Conference National and South) so in terms of having seen football I have about 150,000 hours of the damn game.MATCH ENGINE. Real ife vs FM20Real life:I took some notes from the last 10 live games I saw:Only  7 one on ones in ten games - 4 scored107 corners - 4 goals from themOnly twice did defenders get caught woefully out of position and outpaced by a strikerIn all ten games - NO goals from long shotsIn the FM20 match engine:About 10 one on ones a game - but with about a 10% conversion rate (if you're lucky) - too many one on ones by a long score but this is counteracted by the fact that no-one ever scores from them.Attackers whilst on the ball still easily outpace a retreating defender. This is utterly ridiculous as I've only ever seen top class players with rapid pace able to do this. Defenders never "drop". E.g. Even though a defender is 31 and had 300 games under his belt, he'll still allow a striker to run through the middle cos he's too busy marking someone else. Also, it doesn't matter what height defensive line you play as they'll always allow strikers to ghost past them for the inevitable missed one on one.Players just don't tackle. I mean. I play with a "Get Stuck In" mentality and even target some of their players further (yeah........nice I know) but the team waltz around the pitch like they're auditioning for Swan Lake.Shouts: Some work, some never work.......although there is probably more variation in what works from FM19. Concentrate and tighten up always cause utter confusion in the ranks even though you've justifiably given the instruction on 85 minutes when you're 2-1 up away from home. But they all get frustrated like they're six year olds who all want to score in a game down the park. Overall. I think a lot of the improvements to the "glossy" side of the game are good. But it does seem like SI have gone and done a Disney Star Wars......"Look......its so bright, flashy with all these special effects........its Football Manager - you've got to like it". Even though the soul of the game has been completely ignored.Hoping this gets addressed in a patch but am worried that SI are now more interested in profit than caring for this game. Hoped to be proved wrong.

This is really the worst FM match engine in many years. I would love to get my money back!!!!! DO NOT BUY THIS GARBAGE!!!!!!! I tried. I tried to like this game, as much as I have the other entries in the series from years past. After two updates and 3 seasons in the game, it's fair to say the problems really are in the match engine. This is my latest match report:TeamLiverpoolNorwichShots296Shots on Target132Possession54%46%Guess my final score? Liverpool (my team) lost 0-1 to Norwich. And this with me fielding Alisson, TAA, Ruben Dias, Van Dijk, F.Luis, Mane, Havertz, Sancho, Firmino etcProblems with ME that I notice:- One over the top through ball from your opponent and he's clean through, scoring his one-on-one chance.- Speaking of one-on-one chances, forget about it. You'll never score any. While your opponents score from just 1. - Don't even bother spending on forwards because they'll never score anyway. So I decided to spend on wingers, but they too just shoot into the side netting from ridiculous angles.- Dribbling is OP, my full-backs dribble all the way from their own halves, get into a very good crossing or cut-back position with an unmarked striker waiting in the box and guess what, they choose to shoot into the side netting.Not gonna play this frustrating game anymore. I'm okay with losing in FM, but not through unrealistic scenarios that seem to be scripted to put the players at a disadvantage.

"Wenger out, Fergie out, Conte out, Sarri out, and now, Arteta out, and Ole out." We've all been there. The bad results, the abysmal dressing room atmosphere, the unhappy players, the alleged refusal to sign new contracts. Your favorite football club is a huge, multi-billion euro organization, with players on yearly salaries that are enough to feed small towns. With all that cash coming in, you expect something. Especially if you pay for the Prem. You expect beautiful football, great goals, or even just good results half the time. Most football fans have the privilege of enjoying that on a consistent, week-to-week basis. But, as they say, "You don't know what you've got, till you lose it." One bad result turns to a win-less streak, one doubtful player turns to eleven, and in mere weeks, the rumors of sacking the manager start circulating. And who can blame the fans? They own the club. Their the ones who attend the game week in week out or watch it on telly like their fathers and grandfathers before them did. Not some Middle-Easterner looking to "expand his horizons and make a quick buck." But, before this turns into a rant about football hegemony, let me state my point. All those things; the pressure, the happiness of players, the expectations of the board, the inconsistent performances, you get to experience all of that in this game. Yes, you may not be able to do a Rabona kick or a half-volley from 30 yards or lead your bottom-table team to back-to-back Champions League wins in three seasons because you have it on Amateur. But most of the time, football's not about the glamour. Fin.If you're willing to invest time and effort in transforming your club into the powerhouse you wish it would be, then this is the game for you. It's wonderful and it can't be overstated how incredibly immersive this title is.

Admittedly I'm running at a bit of a deficit since while I was a football player, I never really followed professional football (so a lot of the high level tactics are unknown to me, for example). Despite that, this game series has to be the most baffling I've ever played--In like 15 years of playing videogames I have to say this is the only one that I seem to get worse at with time. Even after consuming a ton of online written/video guides I just can't seem to get a hang of it, so I suppose there is a possibility of user error here. There are a slew of numbers and an appearance of depth but it's extremely hard to me to see how you'd isolate out how one thing effects another...for example, did the changes in training actually help? Are slightly higher stats on my assistant manager actually doing anything? I could go on and on but you get my point. Also, as others have pointed out, the match engine seems super janky and random, and my team's excellent form would randomly crumble without any indication as to why. All in all if you're a football fan trying to expose yourself more to the football world I think it's a fine purchase, but evaluating it purely as a simulation game I don't think it holds up.

It's perhaps a great game if what you mostly do is hit the continue button, but if you are any kind of micromanager the number of bugs make it fairly annoying to try to do anything.Spain and Germany has this B club system that I started bug reporting on in something like 2014 and with the latest FM20 has made the B clubs even worse, what was supposed to be "a great new feature" instead just take all the brokeness of B clubs and mangle it into the senior club, resulting in problems with hiring staff or asking for more coaches (result in the Senior team getting more coaches, so great a unlimited coach exploit) or problems with Sensior players not being able to play for the B team, because the game flags the senior players as unregistered, most of the time the interface to select players to play on the B team don't come up and when it finally does the interface menu is broken and is the menu for unselecting B players for the B team, not for selecting Senior players, so it has no effect. If you manually select a player to play for the B team, the game does this unregistered check and don't allow the player to play, you have to use the broken menu, in the part that is supposed to be the already selected players to play and double tell that they can play, this apparently get around the unregistered problem. Unfortunately something prevents the selection inbox item from showing up most of the time, so it's really hard using the B team to get someone back after injury.England don't have B clubs, so at least I hope that is working better, but then we have a million other bugs, that has been reported year after year that SI just don't care about fixing.Then there is things like PSG is a better club than Barca and Real Madrid, so all the good players in the world want to play for PSG and PSG win bidding wars against the big clubs, but at the same time the frenche league is flagged as being not as good, so all those world class players isn't as good as if they played in Spain/England, resulting in PSG not being able to compete in Champions Cup.Harry Kane and Christian Eriksen both went to PSG on lower, even after my Barca team offered higher wages, I think it was 100K/week more than what they accepted from PSG.When I paid 209m for Kylian, I get told he is improving playing on our team because he is playing football at a higher level than what he got at PSG. Pure random junk simulator, it's just a rather bad game. You can call it the 'cheating engine'. I'm a long time player, this time they made a random result game. You can be the best manager, have the best team with the best morale, still losing with the weakest team at home. You can be first after midseason and with morale top get a streak of bad results ruining your whole season. So, if you don't like to cheat, you will collect bad results at home against weak teams; then you will eventually win again away against good teams. It's just frustrating, instead of improving it Sports Interactive worsened it. Beautiful presentation, broken game (it's clearly designed badly); before or later it will cheat, that's it. An insult to Sigames customers. Just try to exploit the engine and be happy about it, otherwise it will frustrate you. How you do it? It's simple, just remove forwards and add wingers, because the somewhat laughable match engine expect it; it's strong against forwards and weak against wingers, so don't dream about your tactic, the one that it works is the one that it's going to exploit the match engine. It's not about having the best team with a coherent tactic, but having a good team playing an exploiting tactic. Unhappy to have spent so much money for this year iteration. It must be said that it is become an elephant. It's slow in day by day progression (it can take 20 to 30 minutes for a virtual week, so you are going to waste more time than in the past) and the GUI graphics is fat, too much rich and boring like the match engine; luckily, I've been able to find an excellent skin that at least add spices to that depressive 'dull english art with added punk', it's called Heffem and it's made by Krysler, a bold artist; unfortunately it doesn't support very large fonts, well... I'll adapt to it; it's sacrifices a bit of readability (stretched fonts) but it adds coolness, a colorful and complete environment with a great match day graphics. So, all in all, shame on the (cheap) designers/coders responsible of all of this. The game system needs to be overhauled, or better... remade, certainly shrinked.On the pros must cite the inclusion of new roles in the match engine that add a bit of variety (not much, some roles aren't that much diversified) and the inclusion of analysts for scouting. Also, the transfer market to me looks better than before. Scouting, as a whole, looks less intuitive and streamlined. Sigames put a patch on micromanagement, that aspect can be (almost) serenely offloaded to staff members. 3D match engine graphics are better than before (that's what sold me, unfortunately I didn't knew about the newly featured 'random junk engine').

Slightly better than last years in part. Overall based on hours played I am obviously OK with this game but I do have a number of annoyances which come up alot with the hundreds of hours I play. Can be a bit annoying with the change of how responsibilities work, feels like they added more granularity but also took some previous away. (I.e. telling U21 and U18 to not use same tactics as first team is not obvious?) Does not always give the opportunity to include board promises when doing contract extensions.I like the new team selection suggestion mail from your assistant which highlights things like training performance and promises which helps. I like the mentoring groups. Very over priced compared to past few years considering only incremental updates to game and DBI ideally wish they corrected / improved the following: - Allow you to multi select to give praise/ critiicism to players for training effort- more player talk options as at times they only give outcomes that will only result with an unhappy player- Board overriding buying and selling amounts to block transfers , i.e. they dont want you to sell for a rubbish player to get anything you can (and they value the player at 50% more - which no-one will ever pay) - at the same time if you leave the club to auto recruit players they will pay ridicuilious amounts to buy (and wages to go with it). - game needs more NFT turning - can be sluggsh during matches (and I am doing 2D overview so not huge graphic rendering required). My machine is auto spec'd for high performance. - Like last year the in game shouts need some work. 'Get Creative' or 'Demand more' seem to be the only ones that result in a positive outcome ('Praise' only works if your smashing the other team and its mid 2nd half onwards). All others  have a negative outcome - like 'Encourage' - wtf does encouragement have a negative impact (at any point in the game from what ive tried). - Email that tells you players picked up positive and negative personality traits from their mentoring groups - but not which those are (so you can look at have them in a group that focuses on removal of those negative ones).  - I liked before where I wasnt running U21 and U18 teams, but could easily setup friendly games for them via my main schedules calendar, but thats not present (I gather I need to be fully managing those teams before I can). - You join a new club with an existing roster and its like you just bought the team in terms of their team chemistry for on field partnerships. Likewise if I buy two players who played together last year or more into my club - they have no strong partnership - like strangers. - some players with low work rate or weak strength, no matter how many months you put them on individual programs to correct those, some never get better. Any player hitting the gym or doing endurance work as a pro althelete will improve (im not talking getting someone to 20 in each, im talking going from a 5 anything higher than a 5. Specifically players like 50 mil + wingers). - As a manager, id still love the ability to be able to use my career earnings to go and buy a team in lower leagues and build them up as an owner manager. (or keep working say in Prem league and hire someone else to manage my club). Owning a club and be the manager would allow you to avoid all the dumb board decisions and it could happen in real life. (Just look at Salford FC). There is lots more, but if this was my first FM game id be pretty happy.

I've felt that these games have been decreasing in quality rapidly over recent years. The last couple of FM games that I've played, the match engine just hasn't played realistically and there was always a disconnect between the tactics being implemented and the game that plays out on the pitch. So, when a friend told me that FM 2020 was amazing and way better than previous versions, I guess I just wanted to believe it too badly and I stumped up the cash for this season's offering. Sadly, I have to say that I feel this latest game is even poorer than it's predecessors. I know that a lot of people are now sick of the rudimentary 3D graphics of the match simulations in Football Manager, but I'm honestly not too bothered about that. I played Championship Manager when it was just text commentary and subsequently the 2D pitch and I had a blast with those games. My sole issue is the match engine and how the matches play out. Now, I can only imagine how difficult it must be to have a game with thousands of different teams in different leagues and different countries, where any given game played should offer a fairly realistic simulation experience. I certainly wouldn't know where to start creating something that complex. Given the complexity in creating this kind of accurate simulation that evolves alongside the modern game, I do expect a certain amount of rough edges and anomalous occurrences, which have always been present throughout the series. However, watching the matches in FM 2020 does not feel like watching a real football match. The way that the games flow and the strange occurrences that play out on field makes for quite a confusing and frankly boring experience. Many others have identified some of the recurring issues in the match engine, but the ones that I'm most affected by (constantly) are:- Too many goals from long shots- Too many chances in the penalty box being missed/saved when the attackers' stats would suggest that a goal is a very likely outcome- Wide players with good crossing and vision stats on the ball with multiple options in the box and either no cross being attempted or the cross gets blasted into a nearby defender's shins.- Players not taking obvious options e.g. several open team mates in passing range, but knock the ball out for a corner instead.- Team instructions that seem to get ignored e.g. defend wide, but all of the defence is constantly clumped together in the box.I could go on, but it seems pointless to enumerate the issues that have already been flagged dozens of times by others. What appears to be happening is that the game is trying to create an accurate simulation in terms of outcome (scorelines) whilst not being too concerned what happens on the pitch to reach that conclusion. I can accept that being an important part of the simulation experience. However, what I am witnessing within the matches themselves makes it too difficult for me to diagnose what I actually need to do to improve my tactics etc. What plays out on the field seems so disconnected from the tactics that I have selected that it often feels like a process of trial and error to find a tactic that the game approves of and then I'm left scratching my head wondering what the underlying reason for that is. Rather than seeing my team fail and being able to tell from the gameplay that my team are playing too narrow or too high up the field and that it's obviously creating vulnerabilities, my team can actually appear to play quite well, but consistently fall victim to "bad luck" instances. Ultimately, I don't feel like I have as much control as I'd like and it's just not fun to be essentially trying to guess what the game is thinking in order to succeed.The only other thing maybe worth mentioning is that the set piece routines feel like they could be improved. For attacking corners, it feels like my players just ignore my instructions. For defending corners, I feel as though every substitution or change in lineup means that I have to re-assess the corner routine and make sure that I haven't now got a player that's 5 feet tall trying to mark the opposition's main goal scoring threat. I'm honestly not sure how best to overhaul this, but it's a part of the game that I find really tedious.I fear that nothing will change as long as football management sims are a monopoly. There's probably no reason to improve the game if nobody else can produce a superior product and the majority of customers are content to play as Liverpool/City/PSG/Barca etc. and just brute force the game with high stat players. Any criticisms can just be waved away with "You must be tactically inept", so I guess that there's not much to be done. I only write this as an opportunity to vent my frustration of spending a lot of time trying to give this game a fair shake, in vain, but also so that other people thinking about buying the game will maybe read this and spare themselves the unnecessary expense and heartache.

I don't often play sports games. When I do though, they mainly consist of racing titles such as F1, or Assetto Corsa. And, in this case, Football Manager. I'm still relatively green, so to speak, to this series, starting with 2019 last year. As someone who does enjoy football, I felt as though I'd be doing myself a disservice not trying out FM2019. I enjoyed it, of course. That's why I'm here writing a review for FM2020.I will be honest. I suck at this game. But. Honestly? That's part of the fun. A lot of FM's charm comes from the audacious (and scarily realistic) it can be at times. For instance, in 2025, Manchester United re-sign Cristiano Ronaldo for Â£200 million, or something ridiculous. And FM has gotten these kinds of things correct in previous titles. The amount of control you get is second to none. I mean. It has to be. You're the manager. Other football titles such as FIFA and PES offer a more casual experience, but lack any sense of control with what you do. You control one player at a time and have to pray and hope the AI doesn't decide to alt+F4 itself. (In FIFA's case, it does that all the bloody time) Football Manager, on the other hand, is more complex than that. While you don't control any single player, you do control how the team behaves. Do they go for the attack, wanting to demolish their opposition? Do they sit back and defend for their lives to win a relegation 6-pointer or prevent their title rivals getting the upper hand on them?If you are inclined to, you can always start from the ground up as a new and upcoming football club. From the grass-roots of Sunday League, where players eat pie and chips with a pint of bitter to boot for breakfast; to the glory of lifting the Premier League (or Premier Division due to licensing rights; this can be changed with the free FM20 Editor add on) trophy. TL;DR - if you're a football fan and you've not played Football Manager, where have you been? If you want complete control over your team, this is the game for you. Trust me; you'll never go back to the overpriced roster updates FIFA and PES.
