Great improvements already in the beta version - the new features add more depth and allow for players to focus on micromanaging or delegating.In any case, there are a lot of issues to iron out still.- One on ones (as mentioned in a lot of other reviews) are missed at an extraordinary rate.- The fact that there are *so many* one on ones every game also needs review, since it's unrealistic.- Defensive line mechanics don't seem to be working properly, they always allow for strikers to dash behind defenders.- When facing the goal, strikers (or any other player for that matter) always goes for goal and never passes to a better placed teammate, even if the other player is all alone in front of goal and the striker doesn't have a clear angle.- Selecting low or whipped crosses doesn't really change anything.- A few of the club vision criteria are not measured properly. For example, if the club doesn't expect you to sign players over 30, and you sign 8 players of 20 or under, they will still be "reserving judgment" even after two years managing the team.- Transfer negotiation between clubs (or contracts with players / agents) need a bit of rework. Negotiations are easily broken for minor reasons.- Conversations with players who are unhappy (want a new contract, etc) should also be reviewed. They sometimes request an improved contract "just because", and the conversation itself doesn't always go OK even if you promise to offer a new one.Regardless of the issues stated above, I still strongly recommend it. I trust the issues will be sorted, the game stabilised, and all in all it's a great game.(remember this is still a beta version)

Positive review turned negative:I took a 2 week break and came back and some of the few positive changes in the early patches are gone. Wow SI, wow.WORST MATCH ENGINE EVER.Current:Match engine is having some major game killing issues and they seem to be having a problem getting it sorted out. I don't remember a FM release being this wacked out gameplay wise on full release, I'm not feeling confident as several of the issues they have been aware of and after several huge updates (one of them nearly a gig worth) these issues aren't fixed.Inside Forwards and Raumdeuters will not shoot at the goal with their dominate foot, nor will they drive at goal like they should.Everyone should be able to picture the ubiquitous Salah (of Liverpool) goal, where he drives into the box from the right and curls a shot with his left foot.Will not happen once in FM 2020. He gets in the box 1v1 and is not blocked by the defender, but he mostly passes the ball outside the box away from goal, and not to someone with a chance to shoot. Or he turns and drives to the end line or corner of the post and tries to shoot with his weaker foot through the post.This is being reported for other players and teams. They have to have seen these reports, PKMs have been uploaded, but here's the thing SIALL YOU HAVE TO DO IS FIRE UP A GAME YOURSELF AND TRY TO GET THE MOST SINGLE MINDED SHOOTING INSIDE FORWARD IN FOOTBALL TO TRY TO SHOOT WITH HIS LEFT FOOT FROM THE RIGHT.And you will see it is broken.They did fix the fact that no player would ever play a long through ball through the center or over the center.Also you have to play with your defense on narrow defending, but the space is still far too wide when out of possession. You could slide a semi trailer between CBs sideways when set to narrow. I know they spread out often when in possession, but not out of possession.The behavior of the wing backs is not much better, they refuse to cross until they are at the endline, or they pass backwards before then. Cross from deepCross earlyCross more oftenThese mean nothing in FM 2020.I would wait and watch these reviews and check the posts on the Match Engine Bugs thread on Sports Interactive Forums, you can view them without signing up.Early review:THEY FIXED THE ANNOYING REPETITIVE JOKE THAT WAS WINGERS AND FULLBACKS SMASHING CROSSES INTO THE DEFENDERS RIGHT IN FRONT OF THEM OVER AND OVER AND OVER.UPDATE UPDATE!!!! Now they have even removed the above! ALL WIDE PLAYERS are back to smashing it into the nearest defender.

Understandably, as someone who has clocked up roughly 8,500 hours playing the FM series thus far from CM00/01 to the current iteration, I'd like to think I know what makes a good Football Manager game and what has historically let the series down. FM20 does the best job of any instalment so far of improving and expanding on the good and dealing with the negatives.The match engine is fantastic. Players move in a convincing way; stepovers, Cruyff turns, stop-and-go, all represented here in the best match engine to date. Yes the crowd animations are repetitive but you know what, if you want to play FIFA, go and play FIFA.The IMMENSE scale of the game means you might feel overwhelmed by your responsibilities and the sheer amount of clicking you need to do to establish your latest season but please, friend, worry not! Along with all these new options comes a wealth of new staff responsibilities, and you can delegate or take charge at your leisure, Like to finalise signings but don't really care about the scouting side of things? Delegate it. Prefer to find those hidden gems yourself but couldn't care less about negotiating their contracts? Sure, delegate it. Want to keep an eye on your blossoming U23 side but the U18s are just too far off your radar right now? Guess what? Delegate it.I haven't been this impressed with the advances in a Football Manager title since FM13, everything you can think of that would improve the series from FM19 is here. Data presentation is fantastic, player development and progression is as close to perfection as it could be. FM20 makes the complicated things seem simple and makes the simple things seem effortless. To me, this is now THE Football Manager title. Simply put, FM20 is a defining moment in the history of Football Manager titles. Make no mistake, this one is a classic. Though you may not find the next Tonton Zola Mokouko sitting in Derby County's reserves, every story you do write for yourself on this genre-defining game will carry its own memories and legacy and surely that is the highest praise of all.Ps. Match engine is still sometimes a bit of a joke

This is the first time I have pre-ordered a Football Manager game, and it didn't disappoint. I'll happily admit that I haven't bought a Football Manager game since 2017, due to feeling like nothing was ever really changing. But this time seemed different, and how right I was to make the early investment this time around.As a Football Coach in real life, it's great to see more control over the development of youth players and how the backroom staff can help make or break a player, depending on their own skills as a coach. Before I would pick a lower league side and try to work my way up...it didn't matter what the skill of my players were, we could get promoted every season. But now it feels more realistic, which I love. Destined for relegation? Then you probably will without a decent training set up and well thought through tactics.Choices matter now. Early pre-season is actually important and can effect how your team manages the start of the season...player negotiations are much more realistic too! (Though the constant emails from the scouting meeting can get annoying, when you're not looking to expand).Overall, worth the wait and highly reccommend as the best football management game out there!

Shots in 1v1 situations actually end up closer to the corner flag than the goal. Absolute shambles. Players also don't listen to tactics. No point telling your players to put in low crosses because you have small forwards because they never cross low. Most crosses are in the air regardless of instructions. Players can't tackle either. Constantly sliding about and giving away a foul or not coming away with the ball. My first and probably last FM game, for a while at least anyway.

Note: It's been a couple years since I seriously played an FM release. I can't comment as a frequent player on the year-to-year transition, but as someone coming back, I can resoundingly say this has been great coming back after I skipped a couple. Let's be honest... we know why we're here. Only the hardiest of souls dare wander into sports management sims, but you're here, and you're ready.For me, having some of the old features feel like an old pair of boots is incredibly welcome. I wandered right back into core mechanics that were familiar, and that was great. Tactics, signing players, match play, etc. Some of the new features are really great and will be underrated/underappreciated at first. Club Vision is very relatable to real world scenarios, and I did new (to me) backroom staff roles.Also, I do not believe it's new, but I absolutely love the Social Group and Team Hierarchy mechanics! Having both personal and team personalities is slick, and recognizable players on a team coalesce or conflict with each other can either bring teams together or rip them apart. Match play seems super solid, and I appreciate that shouts work! I've started with Crewe Alexandra, primarily because as an American traveling through London and Manchester, I always transfer in Crewe (and my real world experience with Arsenal is already traumatic enough).I haven't messed with training, but that's the next goal. ;)All in all, I am simply having fun with FM2020. For someone that travels quite a bit, it'll be the go-to travel game on my laptop for a long time.

EDIT:Finally in a normal playable state as of feb 2020. Only took them 3 months after initial release. Exactly like the year before.This years match engine is full of potential, but not quite there yet. However, thanks to the patch, most annoyances are done and gone. While not as "fun" as the "all out attacking ME" from last year, this year the ME is more mature and more subtle. More player roles actually play differently and directly influence the gameplay on the field. Finally I can recommend the game for anyone, even those that stayed with FM19 until now. FM20 is, thanks to the new patch, and better all-round football experience than FM19.

As an FM player since 2011 I can safely say that this game is a definite improvement upon FM19.As a lot of reviewers have also mentioned; the match engine has come leaps and bounds from last years game. FM19's match engine was annoyingly repetitive despite changing tactics, players made the same decisions, stayed in the same position and made odd mistakes that shouldn't be made. So yeah a huge plus point.I actually really like the new youth development tab. As a player that likes to frequently bring through youth players, this makes this style of management so much easier. Whilst earlier games weren't very thorough in keeping track of players out on loan, a quick click can view this.Don't expect any UI changes or match graphics to be improved as these are spitting images of last years games. I don't think the UI is bad, but previous versions were definitely better. Most FM veterans will agree.Delegation of staff responsibilities has been tweaked for the better. I personally prefer my coaches to set opposition instructions and now they'll make these changes for you throughout each match, a big plus point.Although this game is far to similar to FM19, the tweaks and changes that have been made are worth investing into.8/10

I'm gonna have to give this a thumbs down. 5 years ago someone gifted me FM15 and I was hooked, even bought the game through key stores ever since because it wasn't available in my country.But honestly almost nothing has changed. The match engine is laughably bad at this point. And that's not just because the graphics look like absolute â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ but because it is super scripted. Sometimes the game seems to tell the match engine "I need team A to score now" and then out of nowhere the wildest combination of passes and mistakes happen which lead to a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ goal. You don't feel like you are in charge. So often your defenders just let the enemy run through, so often your goalkeeper makes an obvious mistake and so often your striker just kicks it out of the stadium.Every year they promise an improved match engine but every year it is a letdown. Also almost every year the match engine is broken for the first few months. The only reason I still sometimes play it is because there's no alternative. But once there is a serious competitor I'm off to something else. It's a shame.

Yes it's BETA, but it's poor. Not really a lot can be wrong with the skin etc. so it mostly comes down to the ME - and it is shoddy. Every Ai attack is a simple punt over the top for the striker to chase - regardless of how deep you defensive line is, how little you press, how tight the marking is (or not). Makes no difference - punt finds the striker/winger/full back in acres of space.Another issue is how many times per game you hit the post. 5? 6? Not an uncommon number.Full backs refuse to cross - despite their instructions to do so "...more frequently".Your players rarely win headers.The old "stand there swinging left and right until I'm tackled even though I have an easy pass on" is still there.SI have had several years to sort out these problems in the ME and each time, the same problems. Makes you wonder exactly what they can justify the Â£35 for - except for a new purple skin of course.Edit. Can't help but also notice how the percentage of injuries have increased since release - and the release of the in-game editor. Furthermore, the Ai will arbitrarily give you a "bad run of form" once a season - without fail. Just now, I played around with a game v. Atalanta in the Serie A. Played the game three times and all three resulted in a 0-0 draw despite Atalanta registering 0 shots in the three games. My team registered between 5 and 12 shots on target. As a test, I reloaded and went on holiday giving my assistant instructions to use the same team and instructions I had used in the previous 3 attempts. With the Assistant manager in charge using my tactics and team selection the three results came in as 1-3, 2-3 and 0-3 in my favour. Why would the three results be so different despite using my instructions and team selection when the only difference is that the Ai is in charge on the team?

The small amount of new features for each year of the series of Football Manager are for some or most dedicated fans more than enough to pay full price each year. A lot of players almost always ask for a new match-engine that will make the game more realistic. Great BETA, loved it. But there are some small stuff to be fixed as usual.*BETA Flaws*- Players are not getting linked (e.g. green line when wing back and winger getting used to play with each other.)- Goalkeeper stats graphic are too bright their stat graphics are almost invisible.- 3D matches are laggy (i need to change settings to lowest before match then back to higher during match to fix the lag)- Dark skin is not actually dark on some inbox messages.- When using searching on drop tab menu, pressing on keyboard buttons to fast access not working. (e.g. clicking E to select England easier, not working)- When saving team selections, box that we are writing down the selection name is not activated until clicking on box or pressing tab button on keyboard. On FM19 it was automatically activated.- Sweeper Keepers are tend to not distribute to defenders, instead they like to kick the ball to further teammates.
Improvement on an already great FM19, including a lot of new features, and is more streamlined. Great as always.

Brilliant as usual. Been playing since CM/FM since the mid 90`s and love the game, so i am a bit biased. The new Club vision and development centre parts of the game are fantastic editions to someone like me who likes to play a proper career( Start Unemployed, with no badges yet). The evolution of youth players and the use of an actual vision of what the Club want to do allows for more long term planning and even more immersion into the game. It always takes me many weeks to switch from the previous version of the game to the new one, because starting over( whilst i have 40 or more years of history in a current game) is hard to let go. But i was still intending to play FM2019 for a few more weeks yet (Trying to win the Bundesliga with Freiburg in 2055 after 6 years in the job and last season being pipped by Bayern Munchen on goal difference) but started a game in FM20 just to have a look at the new features and havent returned to the Black forest yet, 20 hours of gametime later, i wonder if i`ll ever return to see if we could get the Meisterschale. 10/10

The game interface has been made to be bulkier, at the expense of usability. For example, when adding new players during the Create New Club flow, you are only allowed to see 3 rows of players at a time...Another example of poor UI design is the tactics selection. I am no longer able to cycle between all formations so I can choose the one I want. They are now locked behind a tactical style, and you have to pick one before you can see formations. Squad selection page is cluttered, and the mid match view is not intuitive in terms of being able to quickly see what the best sub options are for a particular player. You seem to have added multiple views but they each do a separate thing, which is not very efficient.You had a great interface before that was more compact and easier to browse. Since this game is all about data, you shouldn't make fields, rows and columns larger, so that we have to scroll more for no reason. You are basically falling to the level of EA's Fifa games when you do this.

Some describe football as a way to escape the mundane practices and monotonous schedules that seem to plague us all. I agree with this, to an extent, as there is nothing more fruitful than being able to connect spiritually and emotionally with the team you support on the football pitch. However, while playing this game, the only thing I can connect with is my fist to the screen because this game is utter nonsense, it is the epitome of crap, it is the personification of a headache. Aight, so listen, hear me out. Why the heck do my players always become prime Mo Salah when they are in the box, they literally need 10 good chances to score 1 goal. Not only that, my players seem to become Raheem Sterling in the sense that not only do they only score tap ins, they also crapping miss tap ins. What the heck. Nah, we can't let us this fly. Not to mention that your team could have 30 shots but lose to a team that have 5 shots. Yeah, that does happen in football sometimes, I ain't disputing that, but this happens literally every 3 games in FM. They should change the abbreviation to "FML" at this point, cuz that's how it feels like when I'm playing this game. It's a great game with a lot of potential, but just like my 4 and a half Star Illian Mesiler, that potential was utterly destroyed by the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ of the gameplay aspect in this game. CROCK! Utter crock! FIX YOUR GAME! :angry_face:

If you love  football management games  I strongly suggest you buy this fantastic game - I bought it nearly a month ago and I can hardly leave my computer !!! -  - It only has one real fault in my opinion which I will come to in a moment - as for the pluses - where to start - if you support one of the big clubs and want to challenge for the trophies - away you go - if ,like me, you want to start at the bottom and work your way up - that is where the fun lies - there are 1000's of players in the search engine for you to buy or loan in building a team ,loads of tactical permutations - you have to deal with press (even in non-league), sort out contracts , keep your players happy  if they are not in the side ,suffering injuries and suspensions going through a long hard season, way too many things to mention here - the best bit about the game though (for me) is that you can literally invent your own club (choose your own name)  and customize your own players , so if you have been a fan in real life for many years you can re-invent your old favourites from many years ago with all their own strong points and weaknesses and resurrect them to bring success to your club - I'll end the review with the only real minus point - the match  itself shows selected action and skips certain points of the match so it can get a touch frustrating when you don't see what is happening at times - other than that - a huge thumbs up

I've been playing different entries of football manager/championship manager since the late 90s and I've liked some and disliked others. Unfortunately, football manager 2020 will definitely go in the disliked category for me, which is really a shame because there are several things about the game that I did like. The interface is pretty,  lot of the club management features work well and new additions such as the club's vision and the development center are pretty cool and add to the overall experience. The major problem with football manager 2020 however, at least in my experience after having played this years' game for 50+ hours (plus about 20 hours with the demo), is that this year's version is incredibly frustrating and just not that much fun at all. I really wish I could go back in time and not pick up the demo or pay for the full game because overall I feel that I just wasted a great deal of my time, and a little bit of money, and have gotten very little enjoyment in return. In fact, most of my time playing this year's game has been mostly terribly stressful and frustrating. My only save in this year's game, which I started with the demo, was managing Juventus (called Zebre in this year's version since they didn't have the full naming rights for the team). After struggling to win the league in my first year (ended two points ahead of second placed team, AC Milan) I finally had a pretty decent second season winning the league comfortably after bringing in a bunch of new signings such as James Rodriguez, Cavani, David Neres and David Silva. My performance in Europe meanwhile was truly embarrassing, having been eliminated in the group stage in the first season and in the round of last 16 by Lyon in the second season (got killed in the away game 0-3), despite having a pretty great team. However, it was truly in my third season that things got ugly. After signing a number of great players, some young and promising (Fabio Silva, Antony) and others highly skilled and experienced (Aubameyang, Oblak) I started the season by beating Roma 3-1. This was the kind of result that I would have expected and I was happy to start the season with a victory. After that it was all downhill though, getting destroyed by Napoli (1-5 away) in the second game and accumulating a number of bad results after that no matter what I tried to do. This is when I decided enough was enough and uninstalled the game.I understand that winning all the time would not be fun or realistic but it just felt that I was really not having all that much fun at all with this year's game and that overall the game just wasn't fair. The basic team and tactics that had allowed me to comfortably win the league in my second season all of sudden simply didn't work at all and after I started losing there was no stopping the bleeding essentially. Really, no matter what I did I could not get good results or have the team play well, especially away from home, and while I want the game to be realistic I just didn't feel that it was.In FM 2018, the last FM I played before FM 2020, I had enjoyed a tremendously successful run with West Ham, having eventually built up the club to win the Premier League several times and even win the Champions League, and even though away matches had always proved difficult I never had the same degree of underperformance as in this year's game. I really feel that the game is either not fair or it is not telling the players what they should do to correct their mistakes and have their teams perform better. Overall, I would certainly say that I wish I hadn't played this year's game and I really, really hope I don't make the same mistake next year and buy this game, even at a discount. The game requires too much of a time investment in my opinion to ultimately deliver such a frustrating and unfair experience. My advice is stay away from this game or play at your own peril...

I am reluctantly going to give this a thumbs down. Now, i'm reluctant because i do enjoy the game, as i'm pretty sure anyone who likes football and/or management games would do to some extent. The problem with it is the lack of realism in the matches and results, which has been an issue in previous versions but nowhere near to the same level as in this 2020 version.I will give some examples of what i mean. There have been games where my team has completely outplayed the opposition, i have had over 30 shots on target, over 50 shots in total. The opposition has 2 shots, guess which team wins that game 2-0? That's right, not mine. Throughout these games their 2 star goalkeeper makes absolutely world class and, in many instances, physics breaking saves that would quite literally be impossible in real life. Meanwhile my 4.5 star at this point best in the game goalkeeper can't even catch a ball. The goals the opposing team scores are almost always shots that should be saved with ease. I have seen the opposition keeper save a shot that is hit from 2 yards, as hard as it can be and right in the corner yet somehow their keeper saves it. As i said, physics breaking and completely unrealistic.Now this has been a problem that has come up in previous version of the game, but before it would happen in maybe 2 or 3 games a season, which i guess was supposed to represent that on very rare occasions you may get a game like that. In this 2020 version this seems to happen almost every other game. It completely spoils the realism and immersion of the game when you beat a title rival 5-1 then the next week lose 1-0 to the team which is bottom of the league even though you have 25 shots on target compared to their 1 shot. So, this is why i am reluctantly giving this years version a thumbs down. I enjoy it, you will probably enjoy it, but the complete lack of realism is very jarring and very frustrating. Especially so when they like to advertise themselves as being the most realistic manager sim out there. If i were you i would do yourself a favour and buy the 2018 version, update the player lists with mods. That's the best version of the game in the last 5 years.

Based on reviews, I avoided FM 20 on full price and bought it on sale. I still wouldn't call it value for money. Fundamental problem is the match engine. Players dwelling on the ball, losing possession in their own half and conceding a goal. Players absolutely failing to score 1v1. There is also a massive lack of consistency to performances. EG - I have had 70+ percent possession and only registered 1 shot on target with Work Ball into the Box. As a test - I ran the same fixture approximately 10 times, using different formations, line-ups, tactics, so on. A team about 4 places and 6 points below me in the league, who we beat 3-0 previous fixture. Every single time we lost by at least one goal. Don't but it. You feel cheated and no sense of satisfaction.

I find it utterly disgusting to watch advertisements ingame after paying full price for it.Board expectations are extremely unrealistic. You always need to do better than last year in order to please the board. Also the board always forces you to play certain playing style, which you can't negotiate even with godlike determination skill. Also the interface is disabled to change the level of importance to certain requirements.Player training is fake, players have baked in attributes that you "unlock" via training, but you can NEVER train something that you think the player would actually benefit from.Absolutely retarded training system.Match instruction options are far few and uncreative and repetitive.UI has so many glitches all over the place, for example setting up set piece takers is ultimately bogus.You can opt to have your assistant manager to handle the ultimately boring and repetitive and â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ stupid interview questions, but it will obliterate your media handling reputation, reducing your chances to get another job.If your team fail to produce results, it is career ending, don't expect any job offers, regardless of your legendary manager skills, your reputation is irreversibly annihilated.Old players skyrocket into being useless at a much faster rate than in reality. It is laughable how all football manager game predicted Christiano Ronaldo to deteriorate hungarian division 3 level. And guess what, yet he is still playing for Juventus, how come dudes? To make it even worse, in this game they will NEVER accept lower salary. Even if they play at the level of a 2nd world war veteran at the age of 110, they will ask more than in their prime years. Rendering all old players not just a big gamble, but an expensive money waste.Game loading is disabled during a match. Making save scumming the most annoying experience in this game.At least it's realistic that all the English leagues are full of useless overpriced crap! At least you don't need much brains to do well on the transfer market. Avoid English players like the plague and you will do just fine.Btw transfer market expectations of the board is also ridiculous. When you want to meet league criteria, you need to buy players from your own nation. But they are limited. All the clubs are fighting for them, driving up their price. Especially the good ones. When you sign players that play international level, you will always hear the board whine about their price. Even though you kind of assembled the best team within your nation, they will crybaby about it. Ridiculous.Then the transfer revenue percentage. Every now and then they will reduce your transfer revenue percentage, just because why not. Although it takes just about asking them to raise it back - to make it completely retarded.Oh, god no, the coaches. There are so few that are actually good. Coach training is completely useless. You can't realistically max out your coaches.Also improving your training facilities. Takes tens of years. You can bump it once every year. And you can only afford that if you won every match that is physically possible with your dudes - and it takes all your revenue. Tell Ronaldinho that it takes billions of dollars and tens of years to get a proper training facility together. They can't just kick the rubber in a courtyard, cos that way they will never have the "potential". So freakin dumb mechanic.Sponsors are nearly non-existent. Even if you massively over-perform and somehow cheat yourself to win the Champions league with a lower division team. You will still only have the 100$ yearly backing of the local grocery store. Maybe you will get an extra 30$ offer from the local fake KFC clone.If you manage to improve your team, you will end up having all the old â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ players whine about playing time - even if they regularly play in your B team against opponents that they used to fight against. No they complain, that they want to play against Liverpool with their one and a half star rating.Youth. Omygod! You can have godlike coaches, if you have your youth facilities too low, you will always end up getting complete garbage players.Additional training focus is just a joke. A player with a skill of 5 on penalties can't improve it. Just forget it. Even though if Ronaldo and Messi are mentoring him together. I guess a cripple in a wheelchair has better prospect to be a professional fotballer in reality than your youth players in this game.Custom team actually doesn't fully give you the freedom. And you can't delete your custom players, so if you made a mistake and create the same player slightly modified, it will have a clone.Also the original modified team's members will be available on a free transfer. For example if you sack the Barca, you will have all the top players available for free and suddenly Manchester United will buy all of them, good luck winning champions league with your custom team after that!There is no easy to understand guide how you should set your team to succeed. Trial and error is completely useless cos of extreme RNG.From all the above, the predetermined player skills are the most annoying as this mechanic completely takes out the long term strategy of football. Why would you adopt a certain training if the players have LOCKED-IN skills that never react to any kind of training, even with godlike coaches and godlike training equipment and quadruple training intensity, they will simply say: No effect.So all it remains is a transfer market game. Buy the players with the skills already in place. Because you can't train them as you like.Overall the game is extremely restrictive. Slow paced and annoying experience. Overpriced garbage, with terrible graphics and over-complex UI for the average user.

FM2020 is another chapter in this series, and it remains in some ways fulfilling but mostly disappointing.Fulfilling:- Managing a football/soccer team, signing players, scouting, tweaking tactics- Silly fun- Playing in MLS- Building from the bottom of a pyramid in England to the top- Load/save (best feature of the game)Lame:- The game is harsh and illogical, yoyo-ing results even as you build a consistent deep team that wins, wins, wins. One minute your GK saves amazing goals - the next minute, he doesn't know what the ball is doing.- Broken stat/attribute systems that don't really make any sense.- Your tactics are probably fine - the game is dumb.- The computer switches tactics far faster than a human player or manager ever could. This should be fixed.- Win 20 games in a row? Doesn't matter - the next game your guys will forget how to pass out of the back, always head balls to opponents, and struggle.- Win championships? Your players will still act shocked when you tell them they are capable of beating Manchester United in the Carabao Cup final, and then you go and do it, and then next time, they still act shocked when you suggest they are capable of winning it all. So dumb.- Go unbeaten in a season and then play like they hardly know each other in a game against a tougher opponent. Seriously, fix this!In other words, don't buy this game until it is cheap, cheap, cheap.

FM 20 is a fully immersive management game taking you from the depth of despair and frustration through the tedious day to day hum-drum of dealing with the press to the elation and joy of winning your first cup or league.  Building a winning team team is not just a matter of buying players supermarket style but needs thought about club finances, personal relationships with club players and proper fit into your system. and is he injury prone.If you're not careful hours can disappear while you try to appease the board and the fans, selling promising youngsters to balance the books. In contrast it's a moment of joy when a U18 graduate pays back 5 years of training by scoring the winning goal at Wembley.If you're prepared to give up your sun tan, your job, your girlfriend then this for you.COYWs!

Been playing this game since Commodore (Amiga) version. Like many other loyal lovers of this game, i experienced so many exciting moments, so many disappointments, so many 'last minute' victories or tears. I still remember when i was having my press conference speech in the kitchen while preparing my coffee or my sleepless nights because of a title game in the next day. but i never thought one day i would mark this game as 'not recommended'.For my humble opinion, this game was still ok until 2017 release, where i was not suffocated with too many, but really too many details, which kill the enjoyment of the game. if i really wanted to become a football manager in real life, i would do what is necessary for it. but wait: this is just a 'GAME'. This ,(at least) 'WAS' a game when there were 'acceptable amount' of details. This was a game when there were 'acceptable amount' of challenges,which were still pushing me to use my brain. It now turned out an algebraic calculus where i should take all the tiny hells into consideration. I am sure some people would now say: This is the realism. Really? Are you guys sure Football is something like this? Are you guys  seriously sure that any of the managers in real life calculate the effect of 'intuition' or 'determination of a backup left wing on the pitch? where is your passion guys? who cares about the match engine? Give me my 2D dots back instead but please do not kill my game with your millions of stupid details. This is not the FM i know and love.

Honestly it's football manager and I like football manager; if you do as well you'll like this. The negative review is because there is little effort put into the series, FM has been little more than a roster update with minor tweaks. Just compare it to out of the park baseball which completely blows it out of the water. In comparison this looks like a budget title but it isn't. About the only things FM does better is scouting and the 3D looks better. It's getting a little boring that there's never any real additions.Ootp has you start at any time with the rosters and rules of that time with the players emerging and rules been added as time goes on. Customise the rules. Create new leagues with new teams easily with an easy way to give them logos and jerseys. Adding custom jerseys and logos is much easier in general you could easily change them out every year if you wanted. Put players of every era in so for example want pele and zidane in 2020 go ahead. Feel you can have a much bigger impact on the match with tactics and choices though this is partly because baseball is easier to do that for than football. A match engine that makes sense and works. It runs considerably faster and better they also call their skip a skip instead of a holiday. Even something as minor as the facegen is better. What have we gotten in FM? Tweets and press interviews :).I'd like them to add something major for once but have a feeling this review will probably be as relevant to FM 2025 and 2030 as this one :/.

This is the worst iteration of football manager to date.I've sunk hundreds of hours into this game in a vain attempt to enjoy it. The match engine is an utter disgrace and this game is going the same way as FIFA: yearly updates with minimum effort due to a lack of competition.A company that goes out of its way to say that it is no longer providing updates for a game that doesn't work properly in March, a mere 4 months after release, does not deserve support. The next game probably won't release until November/December, meaning that there will be 10 months of absolutely no updates between releases. I've loved this game since it was Championship Manager, but unfortunately it's been going downhill for some time.  The match engine feels like it's been programmed by people who have never seen a game of football in their lives, the tactical options are full of annoying arbitrary details (sorry, your midfielder is a 'mezzala' not a 'carrilero' so they can't effectively do what you want them to do) that make it feel more like a series of traps you have to navigate rather than a way to help you get your players to do what you want.  Which they won't, by the way.  For the quintessential FM2020 experience, just ask your team to 'work the ball into the box' and watch them pass it sideways back and forth until the entire opposition team is behind the ball, and then either stand still shuddering on the spot like a pensioner having a stroke until they get dispossessed, or give up and smack the ball against the nearest defender.  If you try to play attacking football, you get beaten by long balls over and over.  Try to defend and watch 25 yard worldies repeatedly scream into the corner of your net.Devs, if your thinking was that it was too easy to pick any team and conquer the world with them - yes, it was.  That was the point.  That was the fun.  Please lose the traps and bring back the fun.

I had the older game in 2013, and a lot of things are improved and game seems less random than it was in 2013 (although the engine still has issues in match making). There is a lot more new stuff and better graphics added to the system, and many more clubs to enjoy.The biggest issue I have is there is bunch of LGBT flags almost on every stadium including Turkish and Russian clubs but also when you do other matches in non-registered teams like Middle East, makes 0 sense to have LGBT on Saudi Arabia, and it feels like Devs are promoting so much to spread political values on a football game. I have no issue seeing LGBT flag on Western clubs, but seeing these on Turkish or Russian teams or in Africa, Asia or Middle East makes 0 sense and a perfect example of 1st World Liberalism forcing values on 3rd World countries, and acting like they are inferior or barbarians.Without the forced Western Liberal values on other countries it is a good game, but I hope Devs will either respect local cultures more or make more realistic scenarios when it comes to these politics. After all we had a World Cup on Russia and soon on Qatar and FIFA did not care much except the money part.

This game (and the games before it) converted me into a football fan, and I had barely any appreciation of sports before that point.Football Manager is, in gaming terms, like a grand strategy RPG. You have the grand strategy element of heaps and heaps of numbers going up and down and the initial confusion of understanding what any of them mean, as well as being able to play for 400 hours (like I have) and realise you understand absolutely nothing about the game, and still having that creeping feeling that you really don't know what you're doing.The RPG element comes from your players. Each of your players has their own wants and needs, and you have to balance your match day squad as best as possible. It's not just a case of "who's best at what" (although sometimes it can be) - you might need to settle a disgruntled player, or give one of your younger players a chance to shine and get some experience in the first team.It's hard to show what the appeal of the FM series is unless you really sink your teeth into it. I can honestly say I get ridiculously immersed in this game. You experience the highs and lows of your labour, cringing when your team has an awful defeat and cheering when they do well. Were you responsible? Was it just RNG? Who knows, but it's fun, isn't it? Trying to work out what's actually you and what is just smoke and mirrors is part of the fun.What I'm trying to say is, even if you're not a fan of football and sport, if you have an interest in grand strategy or complex RPGs you may just appreciate the incredibly diverse and immersive game that has the potential to grab you here. For me, players like Alessandro Rossi, Hendrick Weydandt and Luismi are burned into my brain, and I've gotten a brand new appreciation for the complexity and nuance that the sport of football has. This IS the beautiful game, but not as you know it.

FM2020 is a nice game with great improves comparing with FM2019.Anyway, this game stills stuck in old IA defects (I mean, like the previous versions).For example, you are going to play a very important game in the Champions League, and suddenly all your team gets injuries. All season without bad injuries and suddenly you can't play with ur prefer players. Right now, I'm playing with SL Benfica and going to play against Arsenal in the Quarter-finals of the Champions League, and I get FIVE players injuries in the last two weeks: 4 of them are players from my starting team, including mine goalkeeper! Arsenal has zero injuries. I don't know how this can be called "realistic". For FM2020, playing with a Portuguese team against Mahrez, Ozil, Aubameyang, and Lacazete it's not enough, they need injurie half of your team...! What a j-o-k-e.If you are comfortable in your national league (1st) and you want to make a good CL, this can be a lost season. Saying in another way, losing my precious time. You can say all these injuries it's "bad luck", but we all know it's not. This happens frequently in the biggest season games. It's basically the IA being biased in a very silly way and calling you retarded...  I play this kind of games since CM and can easily identify some patterns.For sure I could say more things about FM2020, some positive and others negative, but the way they use AI to bias the game it's already enough to understand what you can expect.

Having been a regular FM player for a number of years, its sad to see it become like this. A match engine with a seemingly endless ability to frustrate you with flaws, 'player errors' and comical graphics. A transfer system that is skewed heavily in favour of the AI. A manager 'rating system' that bears no resemblance to a managers performance as well as the inability to alter club beliefs. All of which SI has been aware of in previous versions but, it seems, would rather focus their efforts on Regen personal circumstances and their own interpretation of Brexit. Sports Interactive have learned from FIFA, in all the worst ways. Churn out a game that is marginally different to the previous one (with bugs that subsequently require multiple versions to correct for the next 6 months), charge full price... voila. TL;DR - stick to FM14/15.

Well, is there something to be said about this game people don't already know. It's a game you love to hate, hate to love, love to love and hate to hate at the very same time. I am pretty familliar with football as a sports, but I wouldn't call myself exactly a fanatic. But this game (and serial in general) is something I can't let go out of my hands. It does have that certain level of simulation value, where you can see what could happen, how would something look in certain conditions and it does always make sense.Not only that, but it's the only game in this world which brings me to the very top and the very next game slams me down right into the ground. To a non-FM player it's pretty hard to explain how it feels when your regional club manages to snatch a draw against a club like Real Madrid in Champions League only to suffer a humbling defeat against a last placed club in your domestic league the very next game. And it's like a d*ug, you just can't let it go. When it goes good, you can't drop the game because you are on a roll, when it's bad you can't drop the game because you're not just some sissy that's giving up when times get rough.This game can really drive you insane. Having started playing FM since 09, I've seen the series evolve over time. You can see that the creators have tried to add more and more content to make it as absorbing and immersive as possible. Unfortunately it's let down by being structurally broken for one simple reason. The tactics and match engine are appalling. It takes away from everything else, as you feel you can't link what you have instructed the team to do vs what they are doing, and more importantly, what the opposition do. If you press, they half-arse it, the opposition dance round you and score. If you sit back, the opposition pass round you and score. Your players can't or seemingly choose not to tackle, meaning the opposition will literally run by your defenders like they're not there whilst your player stands still and lets them by. Your team cannot mark an opposition player in any situation and do not win any defensive second ballsThis would actually all be forgivable if the opposition suffered the same flaws as you. However, this is FM so they don't. If you decide to get everyone behind the ball because you're fed up of watching your team not even try to defend, then whoever you're playing will score multiple 25 yard strikes to the top corner - with no correlation to their long shots and technique stats. If you try and engage in any way, well whoever has the ball becomes Messi incarnate and will happily run past multiple defenders to score  - again, with no correlation to their dribbling and finishing. I won't mention your team's inability to finish clear and half chances vs the opposition for my own sanityThe game strikes me as the latest window dressing in a series that needs a fundamental overhaul

I like the concept of the game. However, I don't like how they've made this game more difficult over the years and also taken away the unrealistic stuff that you can take advantage of, wheres kept the unrealistic stuff that make the game difficult.For example, youth intake is different, something you can't take advantage of (unrealistic stuff taken away that can be taken advantage of).Another example, your players moaning about not having enough players in the squad and giving me only 7 days to make transfers. You can't do that in 7 days, so what happens is you have an unhappy player.Another example, players in english non-league, who are free signing wanting over 20k per week. WTF is with that? I have the media chats, they've been the same for years now. It's boring.Also a lack of flexibility when talking to players about problems, they won't accept 9/10 of the stuff that you say and then get an unhappy player.Previous years I have enjoyed, however this I haven't. I didn't mind the unrealistic stuff, but the game is unbalanced in the way, where the unrealistic stuff that make the game difficult, don't change, but the exploits do. If your going to be a fair game, then take all this crap out, not just some of it.I think I will be leaving for game for a few years, hoping they iron out some of these elements that make the game less realistic, which make the game more difficult to play.

Understandably, as someone who has clocked up roughly 8,500 hours playing the FM series thus far from CM00/01 to the current iteration, I'd like to think I know what makes a good Football Manager game and what has historically let the series down. FM20 does the best job of any instalment so far of improving and expanding on the good and dealing with the negatives.The match engine is fantastic. Players move in a convincing way; stepovers, Cruyff turns, stop-and-go, all represented here in the best match engine to date. Yes the crowd animations are repetitive but you know what, if you want to play FIFA, go and play FIFA.The IMMENSE scale of the game means you might feel overwhelmed by your responsibilities and the sheer amount of clicking you need to do to establish your latest season but please, friend, worry not! Along with all these new options comes a wealth of new staff responsibilities, and you can delegate or take charge at your leisure, Like to finalise signings but don't really care about the scouting side of things? Delegate it. Prefer to find those hidden gems yourself but couldn't care less about negotiating their contracts? Sure, delegate it. Want to keep an eye on your blossoming U23 side but the U18s are just too far off your radar right now? Guess what? Delegate it.I haven't been this impressed with the advances in a Football Manager title since FM13, everything you can think of that would improve the series from FM19 is here. Data presentation is fantastic, player development and progression is as close to perfection as it could be. FM20 makes the complicated things seem simple and makes the simple things seem effortless. To me, this is now THE Football Manager title.Simply put, FM20 is a defining moment in the history of Football Manager titles. Make no mistake, this one is a classic. Though you may not find the next Tonton Zola Mokouko sitting in Derby County's reserves, every story you do write for yourself on this genre-defining game will carry its own memories and legacy and surely that is the highest praise of all.Ps. Match engine is still sometimes a bit of a joke

Great game! Got fed up with Fifa gameplay (finally) and turned to this to get my "fix". Amazing game, lots of tactical elements and so much to do. Takes a little while to grasp everything that's going on (would recommend watching youtube videos to figure some of it out) but very fun once you get the hang of it. 10/10 would recommend

Likes:- Football Manager - probably the greatest sports management sim franchise ever developed- Lots of competitions and players to consider (including International teams)- Decent AI (not too difficult so new players like me can actually play and win some games right away)- Watching my team execute my custom tactics in wonderful 3D Extended Highlights- Having the ability to hire the right supporting staff to reduce all the micromanagement required in running your clubs (first squads, youths, and academy) and makes the game faster- Fully customizable game database- Solid In-game Editor with the option to deactivate it for the puristsDislikes:- Technical Issue: One (1) Fatal Crash To Desktop experienced so far during the halftime of my Unemployed Career game (forum discussion suggests possible fatal issue with NVIDIA graphics cards). I hope the crash did not corrupt my save file...- TONS and TONS of menus in game. It can be overwhelming to someone who's not used to FM games- I notice that my days are going by so fast- TONS and TONS of menus in game. Several features (like managing Youth leagues and your Academy) are only accessible via it's own tiny clickable button inside another menu that may be easily missed.- I have suffered many sleepless nights so far since I installed the game- Have I already mentioned that there are TONS and TONS of menus in game? I wish the next FM game would have a simpler UI.Nonetheless, it's still worth the purchase (especially when it goes on Sale) !!! :DVerdict: Totally Recommended, even if you're not a fan of Football (or soccer, depending where you're from) but enjoy business sim or tycoon type of games. Fair Warning: This game might convert you into an actual Football fan...

FM 20 is the alarming case, when SI releases two versions of the the game consecutively worse than the previous one. FM 19 was an attempt to overhaul tactical side of the game and quite expectedly many changes didn't go too well, resulting in inconsistent Match Engine, where player simply can't see results of his choices, because intructions fail to apply. It was understandable and I hoped these issues would be fixed next year. They were not, in fact they got even worse.Completely unrealistic chance coversions, GKs never following instructions, wingers mindlessly hitting balls when there are two open teammates in the box, nerfed strikers, passive counter mentality, you name it. Adding this to already existing problems like neverchanging interviews, interactions with useless options, unbalanced transfer market, stale world simulation and overestimated reputation effect, and you get the clear sign that SI have stopped paying attention to players feedback. We don't really need loan manager or any other fancy roles, when DoF is still useless, here's your exampleNow don't get me wrong, I'm still a fan and FM is my favourite addiction, but I see 19 as a failed step forward and 20 is worse than 19. I'll keep playing, but I'm concerned that series are going backwards, and devs are applying cosmetic changes to a stale team management, in the meantime messing up match engine more and more. Eventually this might hurt themCutting to the chase, if you pick top club and apply plug and play tactics, you'l have a blast and win things. If your FM experience is playing for underdogs, developing club and tinkering with tactics and scouting, you might be up for a frustrating experience
goat

A review from a player who had 500 hours in FM19 ( the real number is more than 1000hrs i believe) and someone who had played the series for 10 years since i was a kid.If you are new players: It's a must play which improvements from FM19. But its not change much compare to the last, if you jump from FM15 or FM16, it will be a whole new experience. But from FM18 and 19, not so much.Good:- Youth Academy is a good add on. I think they should make it long time ago not until 2020.- Staff is now very active and lively. Head of youth development is actively seek and buy youth prospect at a bargain price. The old version just splash lots of cash, pay overprice for a youth player.- Match Engine: a little more realistic, speed, strength and balance actually show clearly in the match. You will see the clearly different between a fast and slow player, an outpace or a successful dribble is satisfying to watch, also there is fake turn where the attacker trick the defender by dribbling in the opposite direction. A strong and good player will still standing and not lose the ball even taken 2-3 successful tackle from opponent.- I haven't seen any weird angle shot yet like many players report.Cons:- Match Engine: yep, still ME, I gonna break down each situation below.In 2019 ME, when ST receive ball in the middle, he will dribble and usually lose the ball or try to pass to the wing and slowly run to the enemy third. Its usually not end up in a goal.2020 ME, ST receive the ball with a beautiful touch and turn on Saiyan mod. Dribble through both the defenders and 1v1 with the goalkeeper.And talk about the 1v1, what seperate it from real life is i never seen an attacker that lob the ball, dribble around the keeper  or nutmeg. Just a boring hopeful shot.- Player's value: I have a feeling that the value of player is higher than previous years, some player with very normal stats, sure he have potential but no way that guy price is 30~40 mil. In FM19 my player would be very good and it take a top performance season to reach 20 30 mil.

Great attention to detail on the game. However, i feel that the game has moved backwards in terms of realism. Understood that away days would generally be more difficult than home games however making bottom of the league teams level contenders with top of the league teams in terms of possession and chances is too unrealistic. The new addition of random goals being scored out of absolutely nowhere with no build up has on occasion made me want to smash my computer, this isn't necessary and adds nothing positive to the game.Can honestly say that in the past ten games played, opposition GK have had unrealistically good performances. Expected on the odd game but not every game.The better your team gets, the harder the game makes it which is great as it continues making the game challenging however, is also unrealistic in ways of world class strikers going from scoring 40 goals a season to not being able to put the ball past a bottom of the league keeper.The game is highly addictive but unfortunately, there are more negatives to the gameplay than positives. The majority of the above have always been the case with fm games but with FM20 it is clear that these negatives have become a bigger part of the game.

I used to buy FM every year since CM93.  Nowadays I only buy FM every other year because of the minor improvements and I always wait for the summer sale, not because I'm tight but because most of the problems have been ironed out by then.  This year, as always, there is a new look and feel to FM, it has taken me about 40 hours to get used to it but I have to say, I like it, it feels more immersive, you feel closer to your players with better interactions than previous versions, they've actually put some new text choices in to things like the "Press Conference" amongst other things and I'd say its about time too.The thing that really immerses me in the game is the 3D Match Engine, for me, its the part where you get to see all your hard work pay off (or fail) and unfortunately, there isn't much of an improvement in that regard.  Its ok, as it was last year and the year before but it could really do with being better quality than it is.  Don't get me wrong here, I love FM20 but you would think that 3-4 years down the line, it might actually look a bit more improved than it is.The other thing that irks me, and I'm sure, many others is that on release, FM always has many problems, bugs, errors etc..  They have a whole year to get it right, why do they release a game at +Â£40 and then take 6 months to make it playable?  It makes people mad every year, with the money they suck out of us each year, you'd think that SEGA/FM would offer a more polished product on release.  I'd happily pay full price every year if there were improvements that worked out of the box.That said, I'm happy with my Â£20 purchase and I like the new layout, FM20 is a good game (now) and well worth the price, it'll give any football fan many hours of replayable headaches and nightmares, just like real football.

I waited a very long time between games to try a new FM; my last game was FM15, which I got a lot of time out of.I feel like a lot of the changes that have occurred since then have been to the detriment of QoL, and a lot of the interfaces are now more obtuse to navigate.  I also feel that the tactics screen and sliders and so-forth are less impactful on play than they perhaps have been in FM generations past, but that may be because the interface changes just don't sit well with me.  So much of this game feels like changing a winning formula not for the sake of change, but to try to attract new players to the game as if a slightly more modern tactics screen and a less functional scouting page would entice new people to play a very autistic spreadsheet simulator game.  The only reason I don't regret my money spent per se is that now seeing my investment in this game as a waste of money, I've begun to move on from these infinite-replayability games that don't accomplish anything but suck away precious time in my life from doing things that are actually enriching or enjoyable.  In a roundabout way, thank you, SI.

I have put a serious amount of time on this game, not to mention the previous 6 Football Managers, and i have to say that these games are going backwards.Sports Interactive are constantly adding superficial features to hide the engine deficiencies. regardless of the tactics and quality of players you use, you will regularly be met with unexplained defeats and poor player performances. To add to this problem, big clubs will forever be breaking the transfer record, yet when they go in for one of your superstars, they will offer laughable non-negotiable offers barely above the players market value.Sports Interactive are unfortunately going from one of the few good games developers to another run-of-the-mill developer not taking into account the comments of their fans, using Football Manager as a cash cow. The game is poor now, but was even worse on release, another trend SI stick to, releasing at full price for a game that is far from finished. Do yourself a favour and refrain from purchasing this game, and stay away from the release of the next game.

Yes i would recommend it but only just! i have loved footy manager ever since champ man 08, and this years has me right on the fence! i love the in depth detail you can go into this year, i also like the fact that you can farm all those time consuming details out to other members of your staff if you want a more streamlined experience! scouting feels better this year and so does training, you really do feel like your players improve in aspects your focusing on and in positional changes.  HOWEVER.......the game engine graphics haven't really changed in years and that is so disappointing, still okay but at this stage in fifa 14 graphics would feel like a huge step forward..... my main issue and the one that really has me on the fence about even continuing playing is the lack of consistency and darn right infuriation of the ai match engine, i dont get it, i really dont. I can sim a whole league with my custom arsenal tactics and i will the league by a landslide, aubameyang and lacazette  score goals for fun 20/30 a season, play this identical team & tactics yourself manually and you get an average rating of 6.4 no goals from either of them and suddenly Bournmouth have become Barcelona tika taka passing through my whole team and scoring goals for fun, i go from a league winning side to relegation fodder and the only change is the AI match engine, sort it out it makes me not want to play or sim the majority of the games!

I really don't know what I can add that hasn't already been covered in countless other reviews.I love FM, I've played like 10 different editions of this game, but if you have FM 19, or even 18, I wont recommend buying this game. Hopefully Sega listens to the community and fixes the game engine next year because this has been going on for 2-3 editions now.

I bought this game in the sale and it is a worthwhile purchase. I generally buy Football Manager games every 3-4 years because sometimes they are not so different. I am coming up from FM 2017.The best thing about this game is that the graphics are a little better when playing a match. Player animations are clearer and the ball really curves now when shots are taken. Nothing major but it does make for a better playing experience. I also like the addition of the Video Assistant Referee. Obviously, the game has updated players and this is another big advantage when you want to use players that are at your club now (especially if your team in real-life has improved!). The interface is quite loud and a bit confusing for me. I preferred FM 2017 because it was simpler and cleaner. However, you do get used to it and over time it becomes easier to find out where things are and how to adjust settings. I recommend increasing the text size.The gameplay has also been updated to include 'gegenpressing' and other tactics. It just makes an already good game better and it is worth getting it in the sale! 8/10.*For FM 2021, I would like to see goal-line technology and VAR replays shown on your screen.

This game is incredible. The level of detail and attempt at realism the creators have managed to put into it is what makes it the great game it is. You learn so much about the sport on all fronts: the different roles of the players, staff responsibilities, negotiation and leadership skills, and a whole lot more, and the diversity of leagues you can manage in gives you a great perspective on world football in general. This is the closest thing to a real manager job available. One thing I hope is included is the North African leagues which are all top African leagues that have a significant number of the continent's most decorated teams, and a save in one of them I believe would be a good experience.

It's a few years since I played Football Manager extensively. What I can say, over 800 hours into FM2020 is it's well worth a play. Yes you still get 'FM'd' on occasion, and yes that's incredibly frustrating. But I've also nicked a 1-0 when I've been comprehensively outplayed on a fair few occasions.   Having skipped the last couple of iterations, FM2020 felt like a new experience for me, the team dynamics, the training and the new ways of scouting all enhanced my gameplay and you can really feel the difference in the game engine when you employ different styles of football. Wing Play for example compared with Tika-Taka shows very differently in a match environment. My latest save, with York City, has been an amazing journey from the bottom to the premier league and this is the beauty of Football Manager, in my opinion, it allows you to experience fantasy (York will unlikely ever be in the premier league) but grounds it in reality so you get the satisfaction of your achievement.

In summary - a brilliant game let down by a less than adequate match engine.Having logged nearly 500 hours and played through 9 seasons, unfortunately I cannot look beyond the glaring issues on match day any longer. Ultimately, the higher up the divisions you go, the more frustrating the match engine gets.Cons - 1. One on ones are completely broken. You will find that in the lower leagues the problem may not be as prevalent due to awful goalkeeping being a regular occurrence, but once you reach the top divisions, keepers are impossible to beat or your player misses the target 99 times out of 100. The AI misses chances too, but let's not ignore a fundamental flaw. I think the missed chances are relating to match engine balancing - it is too easy to generate one-on-one situations so the conversion rate is kept artificially low by dreadful finishing.  2. Set pieces are far too powerful, leading to a myriad of goals. Penalties and goals scored from direct free kicks are realistic, but corners and indirect free kicks are too bigger source of goals.3. Inexcusably, the set piece creator does not mirror what is seen on match day, so you have a game which doesn't replicate the instructions you have assigned in this area. This can lead to conceding goals that otherwise would not have been conceded. Specifically, throw ins are a complete farce and need a rethink from the developers. You cannot have one throw in instruction for defending and one for attacking, it needs to be split into four sections - the defensive quarter near your own goal, two quarters either side of the halfway line and the attacking quarter near the opponents goal. 4. Goal variety - set piece, cross followed by a back post header from a winger, long shot, winger dribbling 50 yards into the area and an occasional error. I can count on one hand how many times I've witnessed a central midfielder assist via a through ball. There needs to be a complete overhaul of movement in the opposition's half to generate a more fulfilling goal variety.Pros -      1. Everything outside of the match engine, seriously. Massive kudos to the development team here as the games feels very polished and rewarding.  This edition is the equivalent of playing GTA's story all the way to the end, then for a big screen to pop up saying they didn't get a chance to finish the final mission. Damn.

I have played many iterations of this game, and find this version to be uniquely frustrating.If you play as a big club, I think you will have a whale of a time.But as a smaller club, there are insurmountable barriers to success.I have spent a few seasons in Premiership mediocrity after promotion with Nottingham Forest, and the conundrum is this:Every time I try to buy very talented players to help take me to the next level, they very quickly, and without fail, throw their toys out of the pram, demand this or that impossible sum of money, the squad morale goes down the toilet, and I lose game after game, until the only way I can steady the ship is to sell the player. This is not just the case with established world class players: even youngsters I sign at 18, after their first breakthrough season on a meagre wage, become world class divas the next season and steady the ship.So my options: to carry on with mediocre squad players and stay in mid-table until I eventually get sackedâ€“â€“or buy the wonderkids and precipitate my downfall that way.For the people who are sceptical: i got to a point in my game where a wonderkid (on 20k per week) rejected my contract offer of 150k per week + bonuses, all of the squad decided *he* had been unfairly treated and had low morale, and i had a game coming up against the 17th place team in bad form. i played this one game 8 different times, using different tactics and team-talks, and lost every time. The odds are impossibly stacked against you if you have just one big-time charlie in your team!Increased player power is a reality in the modern game. But it shouldn't get to the point where one player is able to scupper the entirety of the game!

If you love sports and you love simulation games, football manager is as good as it gets.  If you haven't played the series, you are missing out.  Think football (or soccer in America) doesn't make sense or you don't know the game.  It doesn't really matter.  This game has the deepest database, most realistic simulation (in-game and over multiple seasons) and gives you the depth of running a whole organization.The 2020 version is the best and most realistic yet.  The youth development and planning portion of the game is the best yet.  The ability to sign and develop youth has long been most gamer's favorite parts of the series.  The added depth in this version takes it to a new level.  I greatly enjoy building a team from scratch, developing youth into world class footballers and making waves in the transfer market.  People have complained about the match engine.  I am yet to see an issue.  I think those complaining have never watched a real game and seen the same things happen.I would try to get the game on sale but would pay full price for it (especially if you don't already have one of the series).  You will not be disappointed.  There is no feeling like trouncing your rival to win the championship for your league or in a cup game.

So far been playing it for near a whole day of game time and I've encountered a couple annoying issues, those being save game failed and a flickering white screen when a match starts which I was able to correct by restarting the game and taking the screen out of full screen into windowed respectively, but I've been massively enjoying the focus on tactics and immersion which counteracts any negatives. The  match animations, although can be clumsy, is respectable and from what I've gathered only the heart pounding moments are played out in slow which makes them truly fun. So far the majority of my experience has been of a national team under 19s. Only thing I can add that may be an improvement is a reason as to why a player would retire early, like a 16 year old whose been called up to the national squad, or the inability to call up a player who wasn't manually removed. There's already so much depth in this game. Definitely recommend this to anybody that wants a full experience in a game rather than just do a couple things and match time.

the game is addictive, which is what you want... however, the game engine is so unfortunately poorly constructed.... you will find yourself losing games that your team is clearly better, but not once... all the time. the teams with 2 shots on target will regularly draw or win a match..... two seasons in, my team is rarely losing a game where the team has less shots on goal, or was not dominant (meaning my team was better and still lost)... almost all of the games lost, my team was a a better team, had more shots, better GK, and then one shot on a goal, and a draw or a loss.... some games can be like that, not 15 in a season.... also, why is my team not winning games like that? Anyway, the game is frustrating as the real football season always is, but if we had 15 games where an EPL team keeper was the best player against your team, meaning the opposing GK had 10+ saves, you would say your forwards/strikers were not 4 or 5 stars, or even 3 stars.....

The gameplay and match engine is frustrating, annoying, and a lot of times unrealistic and doesn't make any sense. I've tried everything I possibly could but for some reason I cannot control possession to save my life. By the way, I am the Bayern Munich manager playing against the likes of Union Berlin or Hamburg or Zwickau and they dominate the game which is the closest thing to impossible that I can think of. I am dropping points to so many draws because for 60 percent of the match I am chasing the ball. The opposition always loves to knock the ball around with no purpose to their passing, just playing keep away, back to their goalie and whatnot and when I finally do get the ball I lose it just as quick as I gained it. Because of this I have a really good defensive record and a low scoring rate. Also scoring sometimes is garbage. I used to only be able to score long range goals from outside the box but now I can't do that anymore. I would even miss obvious clear cut chances that non-pros would make an absolute living off of because the ball doesn't want to or isn't allowed to hit the back of the net.The gameplay is the most important component of the game and if it's this poor in my opinion, what do you really have? Is it really worth buying this game? Besides that I really love the game. Everything is top notch from top to bottom. It is so detailed and fun to manage your club that I find myself playing it all the time. Honestly, I can get over the licensing issues or just find mods online to download. It's just matchdays that I absolutely dread. I almost wish I was not the head coach but rather only another staff member just so I wouldn't have to stress about tactics that are completely useless and just enjoy the other really good components of this game. Update: After playing this garbage some more, I wish i never bought it. Every good thing I said before i take it back because this game is terrible. So frustrating how unrealistic and stupid this all is. I can't deal with this extremely poor match engine where none of your tactics even matter or affect the outcome of the game because its already set even way before the match starts. This match engine alone ruins the whole game and like I said before, if the match engine is this bad, you literally have a worst of the worst game because nothing else good matters. I hate this game so much. I just hope everyone sees this comment before they go wasting their money better spent on something meaningful.

Great game, although I can't believe that in FM 2020 we still don't have the following all-time fan favorites:- a Photo-op before the start of the season. Do you remember the posters we all had in our rooms? The ones with all the players, staff and trophies that were won the previous season. I mean how hard it is to render a picture like that? SI, you have all the tools and brains for it, do not deny us such delights. Don't forget to list the player and staff names as well.- You need to do a better work with the trophy room. Man, put some imagination or send people to see the trophy rooms of big European clubs. - make rivalries and derby games more dynamic and feed it to us as news. If I play 3 final or semi-final games for CL against the same team within 5 seasons, a rivalry could get established. Also, rivalries could get established from high profile transfers. Like Suarez and Coutinho going to Barcelona. Or when a larger team is feeding from a smaller team and buying off their players in bulk. Also there should be some push back against rich and big teams and i am not talking about financial fair play.  - I am still waiting to play as a president/general manager of a club. I know it may sound boring, but it may not be. A lot of us play the game as presidents anyway. Who doesn't click on auto-pick, right? As a president you still have a lot to say about transfers, style of play, vision, etc. plus you will have to negotiate and find sponsors, contractors, staff but the biggest of all joys to get into the dressing room give pep talks or snap a selfie, lol.   *Plus, if you could start as a maintenance and grow through the ranks ;)- And last but not least: Why not have friendly tournaments of indoor football with 6 players on the field? It could be even  for charity. Having those will keep players that are not on international duty sharp. I am telling you, if you add even only one of those to the game for next year, you will make a lot of people happy and make FM 2021 stand out a head above its predecessors and competitions.
